title: harry potter mad gran transforms
story: Harry Potter-mad gran transforms her attic into Gryffindor Common RoomJanice Burnett, , from Cheshire, was spellbound by the wizarding world of Harry Potter when she first caught a glimpse of the films more than a decade ago - now, shes a top fanJanice adores everything Harry Potter Image: Janice BurnettByJessica TaylorReal le features writer:,  Nov Updated:,  Nov | commentsA Harry Potter-mad grandma who has been collecting memorabilia for a decade has transformed her attic into a shrine to the magical franchise. Janice Burnett, , who claims sheaposs a Harry Potter addict, now has so much stuff she needs a specic room for the collection. After realising her Harry Potter trinkets were taking over the house, she had an idea for the mass of items - she would turn the attic into the Gryffindor Common Room, the Warringtonreports. Over the years, Janice, from Latchford in Cheshire, has lost track of how much sheaposs spent on the items, which include wands, a fire, models of the main characters and broomsticks.For more of the news you care about straight to your inbox, sign up for one of our daily newsletters here She even has her very own le-size replica of Dobby the House Elf and a version of Aragog, the enormous spider that terries Harry and Ron in The Chamber of Secrets. Janice says this month marks a special milestone in the Harry Potter calendar, as itaposs  years since the film of Harry Potter and the Philosopheraposs Stone was released. She recalls first falling in love with the magical world of Harry Potter when she watched one of the films at her friendaposs house. Janice said: I’d never seen it or bothered with it and I noticed there was a creature and I said who is that and she said it is Dobby. From then on, she admits she was addicted. Soon after her first glimpse of one of the films, her son and daughter-in-law invited her to watch another flick from the series at their house. As her obsession with all things Harry Potter grew, so did her collection. Have you transformed your house to pay homage to your favourite film book  Email jessica.taylor@reachplc Sheaposs even added a new job to her CV, taking on the role of Gryffindor editor on the Harry Potter UK Facebook page.On top of that responsibility, Janice runs her own separate page, Dobby the House Elf on Tour. Full-time carer Janice has made friends from all over through a shared love of Harry Potter. She often meets with them at the Warner Brothers Harry Potter Studio Tour in Watford. “We all meet up and it Is kind of like socialising - it’s a big thing. I have got some lovely friends and that’s a big thing for me.” Janice often takes her eight-year-old grandson along to Harry Potter meets - as he is, of course, also a huge fan. title: cathedral used harry potter movies
story: Cathedral used in Harry Potter movies selling stones from walls for £Gloucester Cathedral appeared in the first two Harry Potter movies and is now selling stones from its walls including gargoyles going for as much as £Gloucester Cathedral, which featured in two Harry Potter movies, is auctioning off stones from its walls to pay for its upkeep Image: Alamy Live News.ByEd CullinaneKieren Williams:,  Nov Updated:,  Nov | comments A cathedral that was used in Harry Potter is selling stones from its walls for £.Gloucester Cathedral appeared in two Harry Potter films and has now set out on a plan to pay for its upkeep by selling bits of it. It is selling stones from its very own walls for prices ranging from £ to £ to pay for repairs and “ambitious expansion”. The Cathedral featured in the first two Harry Potter movies, Harry Potter and the Philosopher’s Stone and the Chamber of Secrets. In the second movie, a scene featuring Moaning Myrtle, a ghost, and a flooded girls’ bathroom was filmed at the Cathedral as well as another with a warning written in blood. Get all the latest news sent to your inbox.for the free Mirror newsletterScenes filmed for the first movie were largely cut but included the poltergeist Peeves, played by Rick Mayall. In some cases, the stones on sale are up to five hundred years old and their auction will take place on November . Demand is so high that eight out of ten stones have already exceeded their original bidding price. They would not be the first cathedral to do such auctions. Sonia Bielaszewska, philanthropy manager for the cathedral, said: Obviously, COVID- has hit so many charities and Cathedrals particularly hard. Weaposve fortunately been able to raise a signicant amount of money to get us through that period, but we have really ambitious plans for the next ten years for the Cathedral so weaposve decided to be more innovative with our fundraising. Weaposre really fortunate to have a supportive community and congregation who feel a part of the cathedral. So we thought what a better way to connect them more physically to a building which they cherish so much by offering the opportunity to take a piece home.” The cathedral ran a trial auction that went really well, encouraging them to push on with the real thing. The stones on offer range from paperweights to gargoyles weighing  kilograms. Sonia said: Weaposve recently finished renovations, with new gargoyles going up which was a really big project weaposve managed to finish last year. Due to renovations weaposve built up a backlog of several stones, some of them dating back five hundred years. As a cathedral, we typically keep some stones in the crypt for archive reasons and some for historical records. So we found ourselves in a position to essentially have an excess of stones that we needed to find a new home for. Bids have already come in from across the country with shipping already being planned to get stones to South Wales, Cornwall, and Sussex.  Some stones have been more popular than others, with lot , a slender cross marked mortar grip from the s, receiving the most interest by far. Weaposve received some really nice messages accompanying the bids from social media and emails. Weaposve had a lovely mix of the local community, and historical buffs as always. Weaposve also had a lot of people who have found faith quite recently, and want this to be a representation of their new journey through religion. Initial bids that have been coming through have far exceeded our expectations. We have a really well-maintained pinnacle dating back to the aposs which is decoratively beautul which one of the bidders wants to display at the front of their house. title: clean washing machine turning charger
story: Clean washing machine to turning off charger - tackle climate change AND save cashAfter COP its easy to feel powerless to fight climate change as iniduals. But there are plenty of things you can do at home to cut your own emissions, writes Dr Nina SkorupskaHaving a smart meter to monitor your energy use at home can show you how to make small changes to avoid wastage Image: Getty Images iStockphotoopinionByDr Nina Skorupska:,  Nov | comments The United Nations Climate Change Conferencein Glasgow sought stronger international agreement on actions to cut emissions, reducing fossil fuel usage and increasing the pace of rollout for household renewables.Weaposve heard a lot about what nations must do to help tackle climate change. It can feel like a huge undertaking, where the power for change is in the hands of leaders and not ordinary people.But there are ways we can all help reduce our home and personal carbon footprint, as part of the effort to tackle climate change. Technologies like solar , renewable heating systems and electric vehicles are not only changing how we use and think about energy, they will enable us to reduce energy costs and allow inidual households to play a role in helping to decarbonise the UK electricity network.In order to do this to its greatest potential, we will need to upgrade our energy system. The integration of smart meters will help maximise the benefits of renewable energy systems and help us be more intelligent about how the UK generates low carbon energy to meet growing demand.  Having a smart meter installed in my own home was an easy decision. The in-home display, which comes with the smart meter, shows my energy use in near-real time in pounds and pence, encouraging me to make small changes to avoid wastage – helping to reduce my personal carbon footprint and save money. However, this is not just about saving inidual households energy and money. In the future, an upgraded energy system will help to balance demand on the electricity grid. For example, we might see the option of pausing electricity usage in appliances that aren’t being used or the batteries of electric cars being used to power home electrical appliances in the evening, when electricity is in high demand, before fully recharging on cheap electricity overnight.  While you might think that a single home has a limited impact, once combined with other households the positive impact quickly adds up. A smarter system means real-time usage data, and that means demand can be more easily managed, more renewables can be used in the system and a more cost-effective system for iniduals and the nation. There are many other steps that need to be taken to keep global temperature rises below . degrees, but a smarter energy system must be an integral part of it. The good news is, getting a smart meter installed is a step that pretty much everyone can do from the comfort of their own sofa, at no extra cost, and also something an inidual can do that will actually make a big dference. Put simply: the UK just will not achieve its net zero target without them. Ten tips to help tackle climate change in your home In addition to having a smart meter installed, here are ten other tips from Smart Energy GB, who Dr Nina Skorupska is working with, on how you can be smarter with energy use to help tackle climate change: . Turn your TV off rather than leaving it on standby, and turn your mobile phone charger off instead of leaving it plugged in and turned on with no phone charging in it . Ask your electricity supplier to switch you to a green tarf - this means more renewables will be used in the energy system . Replace any incandescent or halogen bulbs with LEDs – they use around % less energy and last around  times longer . Keep your household appliances clean –dirt and dust build up, they may have to work harder . Turn your thermostat down just one degree – you won’t feel the dference but you will save energy and save yourself around £ a year . Check the energy rating when buying appliances like fridges and freezers, and only buy the most efficient . Don’t overfill your kettle - using just the amount of water you need instead of overflowing it, saves you energy, as well as money . Using a slow cooker is a great alternative to the oven for stews, tagines and curries, which need time for flavours to develop. Batch cooking dishes like this saves energy, as a slow cooker uses little energy . Use draught excluders around windows and doors to keep more heat in your home . Choose smart appliances, like lights that only turn on when someone’s in the room and turn off when you leaveDr Nina Skorupska CBE FEI is chief executive of the Association for Renewable Energy  Clean Technologies, the UKaposs largest renewables and clean technology trade association, and Smart Energy GB supporterComment MORE ON Climate changeSave moneyWashing machinesSolar powerCOPEnergy bills" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates from our environment editor on green issues and actions you can takeInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. story: Dad, , who lost power in arm could have died from severe heart failureDad Tom Pinnock, , from Hoddesdon in Hertfordshire, was on his way to work when he was hit with unbearable pain in his chest and left arm that he first thought was a panic attackDad Tom Pinnock, , from Hoddesdon in Hertfordshire, said he was getting ready to go to work when his left arm went completely numb - but he didnt initially realise it was a heart attack Image: Tom PinnockByAdam MayRyan FaheyReporter:,  Nov Updated:,  Nov  A healthy young dad narrowly escaped death after unknowingly having a c ardiac arrest that lead to heart failure. Pub manager Tom Pinnock, , was getting ready for a sht at the Crooked Billet Pub near his hometown of Hoddesdon when he started feeling unwell. That morning of October  he was vomiting and had diarrhea, so decided to stay home from work.But then his symptoms became more severe and he was hit with unbearable pain in his chest and left arm, Herts Live reports.Tom thought he was having a panic attack, something heaposd experienced before - and wouldaposve thought it impossible to have been caused by a cardiac arrest. A day later, Tom - whoaposs a type  diabetic - was still feeling rough and his blood sugar levels were worryingly high. Get all the latest news sent to your inbox.for the free Mirror newsletter He and his partner Jess Clark, , called  and paramedics rushed to the home and performed an ECG. It was then the responders told him the symptoms heaposd been suffering with for  hours were caused by a major heart attack. He told Herts Live: That was the point I discovered Iaposd had a major heart attack. So I was rushed off to hospital where I had an emergency procedure to try and put a stent in one of my arteries to open the artery back up. Unfortunately, because it had been over  hours, the procedure didnapost work. The condition had caused a loss of  per cent of his heart muscle. His heartwas running at around  per cent. Tom said the condition was a massive shock as he doesnapost drink, or smoke and has no health issues apart from his diabetes. Tom was kept in hospital for six days after the attack, but didnapost last a day before he needed to be readmitted on October . As he watched Manchester Utd play Liverpool on TV he felt his right-hand side go completely numb. Doctors said thathe hadnapost gone back to hospital he wouldaposve died.I had no power in my right arm,said Tom, who was born in Ware.I couldnapost lt my arm very well, and I certainly couldnapost grip anything. The fortunate thing was it didnapost spread any more than my arm, it wasnapost my leg, not any higher than my shoulder, so it certainly wasnapost a stroke. He added: I had an ECG and a blood test to which I was rushed into resus because my markers around my ECG had gone through the roof. The actual doctor on site who was treating me suspected I had another heart attack. It turns out I hadnapost had another heart attack, however the markers themselves were pushing the boundaries of going into severe heart failure. I was told that day thatI hadnapost come to hospital when I did then I would have died that day. He was transferred to St Bartholomewaposs in London before being admitted to Harefield Hospital, which specialises in heart and lung transplants. Doctors are not yet certain what caused the heart attack, and essentially put it down to bad luck. Diabetes has been suggested as a factor. His cholesterol levels were stable.One of his pals Ryan Newey has set up a GoFundMe page to help support the young family while Tom rests up.Itaposs smashed its £, target, with £, in donations already raised.Tom said heaposs been humbled by the support, and wanted to thank his friends, family and NHS staff for their help.I was gobsmacked, he said. To the ious people that have donated on that page, people that I havenapost seen in years, people Iaposve only met a handful of times, long-term friends and family, itaposs nothing short of amazing. I think to me it proves that Iaposve done something right and Iaposve touched people in a way that, regardless of whataposs happened, they want to help. Just knowing that there are people out there [means a lot to me]. story: Family with no hot water or heating for two months forced to use oven to keep warmSimeon and Alex Mowle say they have been left in limbo for two months after they had their gas turned off at their flat in Hammersmith, west London, when their pipes were ruled to be unsafe in SeptemberSimeon and Alex Mowle say they have been left in limbo Image: Jacob Phillips MyLondonByJacob Phillips:,  Nov Updated:,  Nov | comments A furious couple say the have been forced to use their electric oven to warm their home after they have been left with no hot water or heating for two months.Simeon and Alex Mowle say they have been left in limbo after they had their gas turned off at their flat in Hammersmith, west London, after their pipes were ruled to be unsafe in September.Now the couple fear they could be left shivering for up to  weeks following the dangerous gas leak while they wait for Hammersmith and Fulham Council to grant planning permission for new pipe works. Simeon told MyLondon: “It took me two hours to run my we a bath.The pair said they have been told they will not have hot water or heating until December  at the earliest.  But Simeon says he has been told the council could take eight to  weeks to decide whether to install a new pipe. On some days the home is so cold they are forced to put the oven on for warmth. For the pair to run a bath requires  pans of heated water, forcing Alex to shower at work. But since Simeon works from home he is forced to face  second freezing showers. On frozen mornings it is just one degrees in the apartment - making the shower water colder. The couple previously had under floor heating but say they are now forced to boil the kettle and wrap up warm. Simeon is also worried that damp is starting to spread by their front door because without the heating on, moisture has started to build up in spots Simeon has never seen before. The website designer claims the whole block of flats they live in has been affected. Simeon added: “People have been trying to get tenants in but they have just left straight away. It’s just been a disaster.” A nearby hotel has offered the couple the chance to shower there in light of their problems. Hammersmith and Fulham Council and Cadent have been contacted by MyLondon for comment. news uk-news haunting-cctv-mum-who-vanished-"Claire Holland: CCTV shows missing mum in ByAdam AspinallNews reporter:,  Nov Updated:,  Nov | commentsDetectives probing the disappearance of a young mum ten years ago have released new images of her in the hope it will jog peopleaposs memories. Claire Holland, , was last seen at a pub in central Bristol, on June , . The mum-of-one was reported missing by her family a few days later but has never been found. In  a -year-old man was arrested on suspicion of the murder but was released under investigation. Today the Major Crime Investigation Teamof Avon and Somerset police has released new CCTV footage showing Claire on the day she vanished. The last sighting of Claire was at the Seamus O’Donnell’s pub in St Nicholas Street in Bristol city centre. Police will also be using an unprecedented method of messaging anyone who was friends with Claire on Facebook in  seeking further information.Investigators will also carry out several targeted searches in and around the Bristol area over the next few days. Senior Investigating Officer Det Insp Darren Hannant said: “We’d like the public to cast their mind back to The Queen’s Diamond Jubilee weekend, which was on the weekend of - June in .  aposaposClaire went missing the day after this signicant national event. “CCTV shows Claire walking along Baldwin Street heading towards the Seamus O’Donnell’s pub at around .pm on Wednesday  June. We don’t have any footage showing where she went afterwards, but staff have confirmed she did leave the pub later that evening just after closing time, around .pm.  It is possible she headed in the direction of the fountains, near the Harbourside, but we don’t have any footage of her doing so, despite extensive reviews of more than , hours of available CCTV. Claire is described as white, around ft tall of a small build with shoulderbrown hair that is often tied in a ponytail. She was last seen wearing black trousers, a short-sleeved black top with a grey t-shirt underneath.  She was also carrying a cream-coloured Primark re-usable carrier bag. Det Insp Hannant added: “At this time, we’re treating Claire’s disappearance as suspicious. aposaposClaire had no known reason to go missing of her own accord and had made plans for the week following her disappearance.  “Claire’s family are being kept up to date on the progress of this investigation and we’re committed to providing them with the answers they need. Specially trained liaison officers will continue to support them at this very dficult time.” If you have information that could help the investigation, you can call the police on  and give the call handler the reference number . Alternatively, you can call the independent charity Crimestoppers anonymously on   , or via their website www.crimestoppers-uk.org – they never ask for your name or trace your call. title: interior designer says tinsel out
story: Interior designer says tinsel is out this Christmas as ‘sustainable’ decor is inAn interior design expert has warned against going for the ‘sparkly aesthetic’ this Christmas, as tinsel and plastic baubles are ‘overdone’ and bad for the environmentThe popular styles for Christmas  include sustainable materials with less plastic Image: Getty ImagesByZahna EklundAudience writer:,  Nov | commentsWith Christmas just over a month away, many of us are starting to dust off our boxes of decorations to bring a touch of festive cheer to our homes. Butyou’re planning on heading out to buy new decorations this year, an interior design expert has suggested steering clear of tinsel and colourful lights – as the most popular themes for Christmas  are sustainability and simplicity.Rachel Epstein, Interiors Expert and Creative Director of CARME Home, has detailed all the in trends for this year’s festive season, from floral tree decorations to the best winter scents.Choosing the right theme Get the news you want straight to your inbox.for a Mirror newsletter here. The interior expert says “natural” styles are the way forward this year, and has encouraged people to ditch the “sparkly aesthetic” in favour of a stripped back look. She said: “This year, weaposre going to see lots of natural, eco and sustainable materials. If this is your go to choice, try incorporating acorns and dried fruit into your decorating. “Unfortunately, the black and white, sparkly aesthetic is somewhat overdone. Instead, simply your interior, go for mainly white decor with very small accents of sparkles.” Decorating the Christmas tree Rachel also thinks we should move away from plastic baubles and tinsel to liven up our trees, as this year is all about “floral elements” with baubles made of wood or glass. She explained: “Weaposll see lots more floral elements added to Christmas trees this year as we continue to be inspired by nature. “Plastic baubles will be replaced with wood and glass and tinsel is another decoration of the past as we turn to soft ribbons instead. “If youaposre hoping to revamp your current decorations rather than purchase new ones, a trick we love to do is to use ribbon to tie together a few small baubles creating little bauble clusters. Theyaposre creative, simple and cost effective.” Changing colour palettes According to Rachel, the festive colours for  include dark blue, green, brown, and pink – instead of the timelessly traditional red and green.  She said: “A huge part of any interior design is choosing your colour palette. The traditional Christmas colours of red and green, and more recently gold and silver, will always be favourable. However, Christmas  will see us steer away from the traditional, and colours like dark blue, green, brown and pink will be introduced.” Creating an ambience This year, interior designers are telling people to discard their multi-coloured Christmas lights and to pick up neutral tones instead to great a “cosy touch”. Rachel said: “Simple lights will reign supreme this year, opt for warmer tones to introduce a cosy touch to your interior. “Colourful lights are slowly becoming less and less popular each year. However, some softer tone lights such as a blush pink would be favourable depending on the overall aesthetic of the home.” Make your home smell as good as it looks Scented candles and room dfusers in festive scents can bring a finishing touch to any room in your house, and Rachel says to go for classic Christmas fragrances – including cinnamon, pine, and gingerbread. She said: “Adding candles, room dfusers or even fresh ingredients to your interior is like the cherry on the top of the cake. Scents help to pull the whole room together and complete your interior. “Whether you’re a fan of cinnamon, pine, roasted nuts, gingerbread or even mulled wine, including fragrance into your home is the final touch! Try to avoid anything too fruity or fresh, for Christmas it’s all about the luxurious, earthy smells.”Have you got a story to share  We want to hear all about it. title: i turned every notification phone
story: I turned off every notication on my phone when I realised I was addictedFor the last six months Ive not had a single WhatsApp, email or tweet notication - my le is so much better for it, and my friends know Ill get back to them when I want, writes Lauren DudleyLauren doesnt even reply to her friends messages until shes ready - and says shes never felt better Image: Lauren DudleyopinionByLauren Dudley:,  Nov Updated:,  Nov | commentsSix months ago, my minute-by-minute habit was reaching out for a buzzing phone. Late-night emails, client WhatsApps, the news, a Twitter notication, FitBit… it didn’t matter what it was. What mattered is that I was immediately available or I’d miss something transformative, I was sure of it. I’d sit at dinner, discussing a friend’s hilariously bad date, missing cues to laugh as I was too busy urging myself not to glance down at my lit up screen. I’d sit at my desk, unable to focus, being pulled out of concentration by the incessant glow. I had reached such a heightened level of contact with the outside world that I didn’t even notice how badly I needed to disconnect. One day, after a long, hard think about this habit, I did something I never thought would actually stick: I turned every single notication off.You’d think I’d be the last person on earth to actually manage this, or I certainly did anyway. I had founded amarketing agencyin the year prior. I had clients, a small team, umpteen social media accounts to manage, inquiring journalists, potential business popping up and I really believed this demanded me to be non-negotiably on, all the time. Would you ever go cold turkey on your phone notications  Have your say in the comments below Fast forward six months, I now find it incredibly odd to imagine my phone holding that much power over me. I’ve turned off every single notication, I don’t open the email app out-of-hours, and I’ve turned off the banner and badge alerts for most apps too. Nothing, except urgent phone calls, has lit up my phone for over half a year. The first two weeks were uncomfortably dficult. When you get a notication, it triggers a dopamine rush, and my own brain was addicted to this “reward”, craving the habit-based behaviour. I felt anxious for a while, semi-desperately telling everyone about it, making sure they knew to call they needed me.After that  Peace. There’s been a million ways this has benefited me in every aspect of my le but perhaps most importantly, I am able to be present, no matter where I am. Whether it’s getting my head down to plan a brand launch strategy or at the dinner table discussing future travel plans. Either way, I am finally living in the moment. People rarely call, and this always surprises me. Both my colleagues and I have realised that we believe everything is urgent, until we’re forced to decideit’s worth interrupting someone... and it often turns out, it’s just not. Clients follow the same logic. I’m a big fan of that. I can’t think of one single moment or opportunity I have missed because of this. Everyone, both professionally and personally, has better boundaries with me now. Our clients rarely WhatsApp, butand when they do, I still won’t reply out of working hours, unless itaposs an emergency - which is almost never. My friends know I’ll reply when I can , but they also know when I’m with them, I’m now both physically and mentally present. As a society, we have a painful and damaging relationship with technology, and an ever-growing notion that with all this wonderful tech, we should be far more connected than ever before. It’s undeniable that we’re privileged to have this access. But at the same time, being instantly available to everyone and anything is simply not healthy.My current wellbeing is testament to that. I used to feel anxious and overwhelmed, and while this might not be the only change I made to lessen that, it’s certainly one of the biggest. It’s liberating. I’ve learnt that you don’t ever need to apologise for being unavailable. You don’t need to give anyone that instant access to you. You don’t need to be actively busy to not respond - you’re entitled to be actively not-busy and still unavailable. Those boundaries are healthy and should become society’s norm. And I truly believe,you challenge yourself to three weeks, this will become your norm too. news uk-news i-went-uks-first-popeyes-"Popeyes to launch first UK store in StratfordByCourtney PochinSenior Audience Writer:,  Nov Updated:,  Nov | commentsWhen it comes to fast-food restaurants, there are thousands of them dotted around the country and thereaposs about to be one more added to the list.Louisiana chicken chain, Popeyes is setting up shop in Westfield Stratford City and opening for business on Saturday, November  and the food will also be available on Deliveroo.Customers will be able to get their hands on a iety of fried chicken items from the menu - including wings, bites, tenders and the iconic chicken sandwich that broke the internet when it was launched back in  in the US.As well as all the chicken, the UKaposs first-ever Popeyes will also be serving up cajun chips, mash, mac aposnapos cheese, biscuits with cajun gravy and they are also introducing a brand new and exclusive vegan burger, the Creole Red Bean Sandwich. If that werenapost enough thereaposs also a wide selection of sauces to accompany your food, such as Mango Habanero and a collaboration with Megan Thee Stallion on a hot sauce called Hottie. The Mirroraposs Courtney Pochin was invited down ahead of the launch to take a look behind the scenes, meet the team and give some of the food a try. Hereaposs a look at what she thought...  Get the news you want straight to your inbox. for a Mirror newsletter here.Until this week all I knew about Popeyes was that their Chicken Sandwich went viral, with customers across America queuing around the block to get their hands on one. A total of  million Chicken Sandwiches were sold in the productaposs first year and after visiting the new branch in Stratford I understand why people were so keen, as it really is worth the hype. During my behind the scenes sneak peek, I got to have a go at making my own Chicken Sandwich, toasting a brioche bun, slathering on spicy mayo, adding two bread and butter pickles and a ginormous piece of fried chicken.I then tucked in and was impressed by the crispiness of the chicken, something CEO Tom Crowley refers to as the shatter crunch.The ingredients may sound rather simple, but thataposs kind of the point, as they were all carefully chosen to allow the fried chicken to remain the star of the show.  At Popeyes, we focus on the quality of our ingredients and doing the basics brilliantly well, explains Crowley. Thataposs one of the things weaposve done with the sandwich is keep it simple to focus on great ingredients. So really good bun, a really fresh brioche,  per cent fresh British chicken, nothing frozen. Then thereaposs good mayo, picklesand I think those components keep it super simple to focus on quality and we keep the price right at £., which is pretty competitive. Weaposll let everyone judge the quality for themselves rather than it being higher priced. The Chicken Sandwich was definitely an upgrade on your average fast-food fare and Iaposd even go as far as to claim itaposs better than the McChicken Sandwich or a KFC Fillet burger... Iaposm already craving another one. Once Popeyes opens youaposll be able to try it for yourself, with a classic or spicy Chicken Sandwich priced at £. or £. for a meal with a regular side and drink.  As well as giving the Chicken Sandwich a try, Peter Genna, the Director of Global Culinary Innovation and Product Development for Popeyes recommends ordering the Signature Louisiana Chicken, with a pot of the Mardi Gras Mustard and a Lotus Biscoff Shake to wash it down. The Signature Chicken Mealcontains chicken on the bone, marinated for  hours in the companyaposs signature blend of Louisiana herbs and spices, one regular side, one drink and one biscuit.Andyouaposre getting a biscuit then you simply must order a pot of cajun gravy to go with it.Biscuits and gravy are incredibly popular in the US but the concept is bound to baffle some customers here as the biscuits look just like scones - and they are pretty similar, but with a slightly more savoury taste. Once you get over the initial feeling of bemusement and drown your plate in cajun gravy itaposs hearty comfort food at its best. Trust me. So whataposs the verdict Ultimately, Iaposd say I was a Popeyes convert and Iaposm excited for everyone to get to have a taste of Louisiana in London. The prices are pretty generous for the portion sizes and the fried chicken was super crunchy and full of flavour - with the hot wings and spicy sandwich packing a real kick.I love that Popeyes is staying true to its American roots and offering customers something thataposs familiarbut also completely dferent, with more unusual items on the menu like biscuits and gravy.Also, itaposs worth noting that the company, while being an iconic American brand, is going to be sourcing  per cent of ingredients locally in the UK instead of importing from the US. Theyaposve also signed the Better Chicken Commitment, which aims to improve the lives of chickens in their supply chain. If you enjoy fried chicken and want to try something new, then this is definitely the place for you. Owned by Restaurant Brands International, which also owns Burger King, Popeyes already has  branches in Europe, the Middle East and Africa. Over in the US, the menu also features items such as cajun fried shrimp and a flounder sandwich. If all goes well with the UK launch we could see similar items added over here in the future. Popeyes have yet to confirm where  in the UK they will be opening, but CEO Tom Crowley said he is looking forward to the expansion, which will feature dine-in restaurants and drive-thrus. Our vision for our UK launch is ambitious and bold. All our locations will be carefully chosen in communities that echo the Louisianan spirit synonymous with Popeyes. We’re looking forward to unveiling our next sites in due course, and revealing more about our expansion into new locations in  and beyond, he told The Mirror.This launch comes after another US chain recently opened, with Wendyaposs bringing more burgers to the UK, after disappearing from the high street  years ago. news uk-news liverpool-bomber-wanted-cause-maximum-"Liverpool: CCTV captures moment taxi explodes at hospitalByChris HughesDefence and Security EditorNick SommerladInvestigations EditorPaul ByrneLucy ThorntonHollie Bone:,  Nov Updated:,  Nov Liverpool taxi bomber Emad Al Swealmeen wanted to cause death and mayhem at a maternity ­hospital packed with women and babies, terror experts fear. The -year-old Syrian refugee’s murderous mission was thwarted by heroic cabbie David Perry, who is said to have locked him in the vehicle as he detonated his home-made device. It is also feared the type of bomb he used could indicate that an al-Qaeda cell was involved, as the country’s terror threat alert was raised from substantial to severe – meaning another attack is now “highly likely”. Al Swealmeen is believed to have had mental health problems and according to pals had been sectioned for brandishing a kne in the city centre before launching his death bid.  And it was tonight reported his intended Remembrance Day target was church-goers who helped him convert from Islam to Christianity. But police said he switched his deadly intentions to Liverpool Women’s Hospital after his route in a taxi was blocked by traffic and road closures and told David to head there. A senior former intelligence source said: “The bomber intended to enter the hospital and trigger his device, but for some reason it went off early and failed properly to initiate.  “Had he successfully set off the bomb inside it would have been extremely bloody and horric. “We believe this was a partial ­explosion, clearly from a device at high-chest level, aimed at causing many casualties.” Al Swealmeen, who died inside the burning cab, converted from Islam in Liverpool’s Anglican ­cathedral in March . He spent eight months living with devoted Christians Malcolm and ­Elizabeth ­Hitchcott at their home in the Aigburth district.  The couple today told of their shock at hearing the “quiet and well mannered” man, who was also quite artistic, allegedly intended to bomb women and children. Former soldier Mr Hitchcott­ said: “It’s terribly sad. We loved him. He was a lovely guy and we are shocked. “We are shocked because a less likely ­candidate you could not imagine.  “He first came to the ­cathedral in August  and wanted to convert to ­Christianity. He was ­destitute at that time and we took him in.” Mr and Mrs Hitchcott told how Al Swealmeen arrived in the UK via Dubai in  seeking asylum. It is believed his case had been decided and rejected at first. Motor racing fan Al Swealmeen, who is said to have called himself Enzo Almeni after Ferrari founder Enzo Ferrari, then renewed his ­application in November .  But the couple said he never spoke about his time in Syria or Iraq. They said he was born in Iraq where his mum was from. His dad was Syrian. Armed police arrested three men in Kensington, a mile from the blast, on Sunday at .pm. They are aged ,  and . A fourth aged  was held today close to Sefton Park. ­Neighbours told of the drama as officers raided the property. One policeman could be seen with a gun on a ladder overlooking a garden behind the raided terraced house. There was a shout of “armed police” and another officer appears to break down the wooden fence or gate before storming the garden. A man in a white T-shirt looked through the back door, before ­disappearing. There were then shouts of “get out of the house, do not move, hands on your head now” as the man re-emerges and follows instructions to lie on the ground.  Resident Keith Ford, , said: “Police were everywhere. There were two officers with big guns, they looked like machine guns, pointed at the house. “One of them must have come to the door as I heard the policeman say to him, ‘Hands in the air’. “But he must have refused and gone back into the house because I then heard the policeman say, ‘He might have a gun in his pocket.’”  Matthew Heitman, , who lives opposite the raided house, added: “Two of the men were marched out at gunpoint and they had them up against the wall. There wasn’t any kind of struggle, they just walked out. “The people living there had not long moved in.” Jimmy Ashworth, , who runs Jimmy’s cafe was evacuated at am today as the further arrest took place.  He said: “They said that my le was in danger, that’s all they could tell me.” Photographs taken within the cordoned area at am showed a man in a black puffer jacket, black ­trousers and white trainers being held. One -year-old ­resident, who gave her name as Amy, said: “It’s unbelievable to think we were living  yards away from a bomb factory. I haven’t slept all night.”  Today Army specialists carried out a controlled explosion near Sefton Park “as part of the ongoing” probe into the blast, according to police. There have been warnings for weeks that terror groups are growing in Afghanistan following the bungled evacuation and could attack the West. The intelligence source added: “This is the attack we have been warning would take place.  “We are likely to see more in the coming months. Terrorists globally have been given confidence since the Afghan ­withdrawal and they have more space and time to devote to extending their violence worldwide.” Boris Johnson slammed the ­“sickening attack.” The PM said: “My thoughts remain with all those affected and I want to pay tribute to the emergency services who responded as always with such speed and professionalism.  “The British people will never be cowed by terrorism.” The Liverpool attack came just two weeks after Tory MP David Amess was stabbed to death at his surgery in an alleged terror incident. Home Secretary Priti Patel said the terror threat has been raised because “what we saw yesterday is the second incident in a month”.  NHS chiefs have ordered an overhaul of security at hospitals across England’s  health trusts. Cab driver David fled the vehicle after the explosion and just moments before it was engulfed in flames. story: No-nonsense boss tells recruits dont come in stinking like p*** in brutal job advertIn the no-nonsense job ad, Craig Harker says the restaurants are "taking over" and he needs "a load of awesome people" to staff new venues opening up across the countryCraig says he needs a load of awesome people to staff new venues opening up across the country Image: GazetteByKelley Price:,  Nov | commentsThe boss of a fast-growing pub chain has set out expectations for workers, including not “stinking of drink or “p***” and not needing to be shown what to do “again and again and again”. In the no-nonsense job ad, Craig Harker, who owns George Pub  Grills, says the restaurants are taking over and he needs a load of awesome people to staff new venues opening up across the country. The business wants quick learners with the right work ethic, who can hit the ground running and be smart and presentable, he said.However, the straight-talking landlord goes on to list a few more prerequisites he expects from successful candidates, Teeside Live reports, They include not coming in absolutely stinking of drink or p*** after a night out.Get all the latest news sent to your inbox.for the free Mirror newsletter Craig’s job advert said: Right then, as we grow as a business and open up new venues across Teesside we also need to recruit a load of awesome people to join our teams in Stockton, Middlesbrough, Redcar as well as Sadberge, Darlington. Yep, weaposre taking over. Youaposve all seen the George on FB and know the awesome food we knock out. Parmos banging, Smash burgers unreal - and unbelievable Sunday dinners. Have you worked in a kitchen  Are you a chef or cook  Are you a quick learner and not one for these that need showing again and again and again and still get it ****ing wrong lol  We need people who can hit the ground running. Donapost know how much time weaposve wasted on the wrong people, so please only applyyou have the work ethic to succeed. Chefs are a dying breed at the minute due to people leaving the industry, Craig adds. Iaposll personally put the time and effort in to train the right people. You must be smart, presentable and not come in absolutely stinking of drink or p*ss after a night out. It doesnapost take much to wash and look after your presentation.  Iaposll even throw in a tooth brush and a George chefs jacket, he joked. If you need a mint before the interview then thereaposs a shop next door. If you feel your pits are a little fruity then nip and buy some deodorant quickly before the interview. Hospitality takes away your weekends, he continued, so be prepared to lose your social le. Donapost worry, Iaposll open up the Irish Bar on Wednesdays and Sundays just for you lot with discounted drinks all night with no work the next day. Iaposll even get in karaoke first singing a bit of Letaposs Get Ready to Rumble. If you have a spare Sunday, then thataposs absolutely rammed so I will even offer the right people looking for extra income just Sunday hours! The George is looking for head chefs, kitchen assistants, bar staff, Sunday delivery drivers and pot washers. Roles are available across its Stockton Redcar Middlesbrough and Darlington venues. Craig is also looking for people to fill admin roles and online marketing consultants to join them at Stockton Business Hub and Dad Loves Food HQ. The landlord saysanyone is interested after taking all that in, they can drop him a DM to apply. If you fancy working for an awesome boss, he says, then come and have a chat with me. Plus free cake Sundays lol. % off when at work and % when not at work. Bosh. story: One in four children clinically obese as rates see record increase in Covid pandemicThe pandemic saw junk food companies used the opportunity to keep their unhealthy products centre stage in children’s minds, say the Obesity Health Alliance, and more than a quarter of pupils are now clinically obese by the time they finish primary school pinching his fat stomach" content"https:i-prod.mirror incoming article.ece ALTERNATES n _Overweight-boy---pinching-his-fat-stomach.jpg" width"" "" One in fourt kids are now obese Image: Getty ImagesByMartin BagotHealth and Science editor:,  Nov | commentsObesity rates in primary school children have seen a record increase during the pandemic. More than a quarter of pupils in England are now clinically obese by the time they finish primary school. Rates in reception class increased by almost half between   and   according to the National Child Measurement Programme Rises in this age group as well as Year  were the highest annual increase since the programme was launched in . Among reception-aged children - those aged four and five - the rates of obesity rose from .% in   to .% in  . And among Year  pupils - those in their last year of primary school aged  and  - obesity prevalence increased from % in   to .% in  .  Caroline Cerny, lead at the Obesity Health Alliance, said: “There are several aspects of the pandemic that are likely to have contributed to this increase in child obesity levels. “But it is very clear from data showing increases in sales of confectionery, biscuits and fast food that junk food companies used the opportunity to keep their unhealthy products centre stage in children’s minds. “We need to break the junk food cycle to improve children’s health. “We need the Government to take stronger action to improve everyday food and drink with a levy on food companies to incentivise them to improve.” Childhood obesity rates are twice as high in the most deprived communities compared to the least. David Fothergill, chair of the Local Government Association’s wellbeing board, said: “Childhood obesity is one of the greatest public health challenges we face, made all the more dficult by the impact of the pandemic on children’s activities and lestyles. “As these worrying figures show, there is still much to do to encourage healthier eating and habitswe are to avoid today’s obese children becoming tomorrow’s obese adults.“Investment in councils’ public health services now will reap benefits for everyone longer-term, including for theNHS .”The numbers The proportion of children who were a healthy weight dropped between   and  . Among Year  pupils, .% were deemed to be a healthy weight, down from .% the year previously. Among reception children, seven in were classed as having a healthy weight, down from .% the year previously. The proportion of all children who were either overweight or obese was .% in reception and .% in Year .It comes a day after NHS England announced that thousands of severely obese children will be sent to new ‘fat camps’.Some  specialist clinics are being set up across England. title: paramedic said could only help
story: Paramedic claims she could only help one patient in  hours due to lack of bedsFaye Shepherd, a student paramedic at the South Western Ambulance Service, has said large queues at Truro hospital in Cornwall has stopped paramedics from seeing patientsThe student paramedic snapped a photo of the long queue Image: James Dadzitis   SWNSByEd CullinaneMilo BoydNews Reporter:,  Nov Updated:,  Nov | commentsA student paramedic claims her ambulance managed to reach only one patient in a  hour sht - due to a lack of hospital beds.Faye Shepherd regularly tweets her anger at her crew in Truro, Cornwall, being stuck in queues of twenty or more ambulances outside hospital.Posting at :am today she said: During last night’s .hr sht, we saw ONE patient. aposaposThat’s not because there’s no demand, but because we were stuck at hospital for the entire duration, waiting for bed space.Meanwhile, people are dying waiting for ambulances. What part of this is sustainable Sajid Javid  Faye, who lists herself as Ambulance ECA  Student Paramedic at South Western Ambulance Service, made her comments as the NHS faces unprecedented pressure ahead of the deep winter months. Alarming data shows that there are almost half as many fewer beds free now than during the peak of the pandemic in January. While Covid hospitalisations have dropped signicantly - from around , daily admissions at the beginning of the year to around , eleven months on - other, non-Covid related pressures have soared. The build up in demand has left health chiefs feelings deeply concerned.A survey of  NHS leaders in England finds the health service already at “tipping point”, according to NHS Confederation. Now % of the leaders think the demands on their organisation are unsustainable, and % believe a lack of staffing in the NHS as a whole is putting patient safety and care at risk. Matthew Taylor, the chief executive of the NHS Confederation, told the : “Almost every healthcare leader we’ve spoken to is warning that the NHS is under unsustainable pressure, and they are worried the situation will worsen, as we head into deep midwinter, unless action is taken. They are also sounding alarm bells over risks to patient safetytheir services become overwhelmed, on top of a severe workforce crisis. Faye is another health worker determined to sound the alarm. aposaposCurrently rd in the queue, out of  ambulance crews waiting to enter the emergency department, she tweeted midway through October. aposaposThere’s a palpable sense of concern amongst staff, hearing general broadcast after general broadcast with few remaining resources available to send. aposaposIt’s not even winter. Help.aposapos A spokesperson from South Western Ambulance Service NHS Foundation Trust said it was experiencing the highest-ever level of sustained demand on our service and that response times are affected as a result. We are losing many more hours compared with recent years which causes our ambulances to queue outside hospitals and unable to respond to other patients and has an inevitable impact on the service we can provide, they said. This is a health system problem which therefore demands a system solution. It is an absolute priority for us and our NHS partners to reduce these delays, so we can be there for our patients, while prioritising those who are most seriously injured and ill. Patients who need urgent medical help or advice are encouraged to visit or to call , which is free and available  . This will ensure they get the right care, and the ambulance service can focus on those most in need. For on-going or non-urgent medical concerns orthey need medicines, people should contact their local GP surgery or a local pharmacy. title: people smuggler admits involvement scheme
story: People smuggler admits involvement in scheme which caused deaths of  migrants in lorryDragos Stefan Damian, , pleaded guilty to conspiracy to assist unlawful immigration which led to the deaths of dozens of migrants being transported in a refrigerated lorry trailerPolice are seen at the scene where bodies were discovered in a lorry container, in Grays, Essex, in  Image: REUTERSByEmily PenninkRyan MerrieldReporter:,  Nov | comments A people smuggler has admitted his part in a profitable criminal enterprise which ended in the deaths of  migrants.Dragos Stefan Damian, , was extradited from Italy to face a UK court following the investigation into the deaths of Vietnamese men, women and children. The victimsapos bodies were found in a refrigerated lorry trailer after it was transported by ferry from Zeebrugge to Purfleet in Essex, in October . Earlier this year, other members of the people smuggling gang were jailed at the Old Bailey for their involvement. Damian had been arrested on June  just outside Milan and sent back to Britain in September. On Tuesday, he appeared at the Old Bailey by video link from Chelmsford prison.  With the assistance of an Italian interpreter, he pleaded guilty to conspiracy to assist unlawful immigration between May ,  to October , . Prosecutor Jonathan Polnay said Damianaposs principal involvement in the plot was by personally and allowing others to use his van to pick up migrants from Collingwood Farm in Essex after they were transported into the country. Sentencing was adjourned until January  next year before Mr Justice Sweeney. Earlier, another gang member, Valentin Calota was ordered to pay the victimsapos families more than £,.  Calota was paid £ plus expenses to drive one vanload of migrants from Essex to London days before the fatal run. The -year-old, from Birmingham, was jailed for four and a half years earlier this year. Calota appeared at the Old Bailey for his confiscation hearing by video link from HMP Huntercombe and was assisted by a Romanian interpreter. The court heard that Calota had benefited from his criminal lestyle to the amount of £,..  The money in sterling, euro and Romanian leu had been seized by police upon his arrest. Mr Polnay said: The prosecution had considered submitting to this court the benefit was higher. However, given we understand Mr Calota is to be deported relatively shortly from this country we consider there to be littleany benefit in an academic exercise in asserting that he had a higher benefit. Judge Mark Lucraft QC ordered that the entire sum of £,. be confiscated and paid as compensation to the victimsapos families. Other gang members are due to face confiscation hearings later this week. Previously, the court had heard the criminal operation was long-running and profitable, with the smugglers standing to make more than £ million in October  alone.  A total of seven smuggling trips were identied between May  and October  , with migrants paying up to £, for a VIP service. Migrants would board lorries at a remote location on the continent to be transported to Britain where they would be picked up by a fleet of smaller vehicles for transfer to a safe house until payment was received. Some of the trips were thwarted by border officials and residents in Orsett, Essex, had repeatedly reported migrants being dropped off to the police. Yet the smuggling operation was not stopped until after the tragic journey. The families of the victims in Vietnam and Britain have previously spoken of their loss and hardship. news uk-news prince-andrews-nightmare-le-newsnight-"Prince Andrew: Expert on chances ofto public leByJenner NewtonRoyal Features Writer:,  Nov  Itaposs been two years since Prince Andrew sat down for his widely-criticised interview with Emily Maitlis from BBC Newsnight. The interview, broadcast in  and described by many as a “car crash”, saw Andrew speak atabout his association with the convicted sex offender Jeffrey Epstein.Andrew vehemently denied any accusations of wrongdoing over his links to Epstein, including allegations he had sex with Virginia Giuffre when she was  years old. He also declined to say he regretted the friendship with Epstein, with his memorable answers including details of his visit to Pizza Express and saying he was medically unable to sweat.  In the days after the interview, his le began to change considerably and he has now stepped away from public duties. Here we look at his two years since the interview... Stepping down from public dutiesIt was just days after the interview was broadcast that Andrew sensationally quit public le for the foreseeable future.In a statement, approved by the Queen, the Duke of York said it had become clear to him that my former association with Jeffrey Epstein has become a major disruption to my family’s work.He expressed sympathy for the victims of the convicted sex offender and disgraced financier, saying he hoped they could rebuild their lives. Love the royals for the Mirroraposs daily newsletter to get all the latest news on the Queen, Charles, Kate, Wills, Meghan, Harry and the rest of The Firm. Click here to sign up. He said: It has become clear to me over the last few days that the circumstances relating to my former association with Jeffrey Epstein has become a major disruption to my family’s work and the valuable work going on in the many organisations and charities that I am proud to support. Therefore, I have asked Her MajestyI may step back from public duties for the foreseeable future, and she has given her permission. I continue to unequivocally regret my ill-judged association with Jeffrey Epstein. His suicide has left many unanswered questions, particularly for his victims, and I deeply sympathise with everyone who has been affected and wants some form of closure. I can only hope that, in time, they will be able to rebuild their lives. Of course, I am willing to help any appropriate law enforcement agency with their investigations,required. Low-key ChristmasJust weeks after the interview, the Royal Family celebrated Christmas  at Sandringham - and as is tradition greeted well-wishers as they walked to church.But rather than attending this service at around am, Andrew attended the more low-key service, which takes place earlier in the morning - missing the crowds. Misses out on honour  Months after the interview in February , Andrew turned  - and he would have been in line for a Navy promotion.It would have followed advancements to Rear Admiral on his th birthday and Vice Admiral when he was . But he declined the promotion to the rank of Admiral ahead of turning .The move would have been in line with a long-standing policy under which senior royals are treated asthey had stayed in the Armed Forces and are promoted to higher ranks as a result. A Buckingham Palace spokeswoman said at the time: “By convention, the Duke of York would be in line for military promotion on his th birthday. Following the decision by His Royal Highness to step back from public duties for the foreseeable future, the Duke of York has asked the Ministry of Defencethis promotion might be deferred until such time that His Royal Highness s to public duty.” Wedding photo absence There was a happy occasion in the York family in July  when Princess Beatrice wed husband Edoardo Mapelli Mozzi in a low-key ceremony in Windsor under Covid restrictions. Fewer than  guests attended – a far cry from the  wedding of Bea’s sister , Princess Eugenie, to Jack Brooksbank in , which was broadcast on TV. But when it came to the official wedding photos released to the public, Beatriceaposs dad Andrew didnapost figure in any of them.The Queen and Prince Philip were the only royals shown with the beaming bride and her new husband.The decision to release snaps without him was thought to have been taken by the family alongside advice from courtiers. Royals aposblock apos  After the sad death of his father Prince Philip, Andrew talked to television crews outside All Saints Chapel, Windsor Lodge, to express the feelings of the Royal Family. He also very briefly appeared in a documentary about his fatheraposs le in September.However, it was reported last month that royal sources have claimed his siblings have ruled out anyback to public le for Andrew.An insider told the Sunday Times that a meeting was held last January where Prince Charles, Princess Anne and Prince Edward were in agreement that their brother should never be allowed toto public le.They said: “There is no way in the world he’s ever coming back, the family will never let it happen.”The source also claimed that Prince William was annoyed about Andrew’s attitude since the scandal has emerged, saying it’s what “really gets” to him.Legal battle Earlier this year, Virginia Giuffre began the process of suing Andrew in a civil case in New York for allegedly sexually assaulting her when she was a teenager. She alleges she was told by Epstein and British socialite Ghislaine Maxwell to have sex with the Prince at Epsteinaposs mansion in New York and at other locations. The prince has always denied the allegations and said he has “no recollection” of ever meeting herEarlier this month, a judge said Andrew should be prepared for a trial late next year on accusations.Speaking in a teleconference, US District Judge Lewis Kaplan said he anticipated the trial on Virginia Giuffre’s civil claims would begin between September and December . news uk-news prince-charles-duchess-cornwall-begin-"Prince Charles arrives in Jordan ahead of tourByRussell MyersRoyal editor:,  Nov Updated:,  Nov | commentsThe Duchess of Cornwall was treated to an electrying tour of Amman today - hosted by Queen Rania driving a top of the range Tesla in stiletto heels.Camilla accompanied the Queen for the  minute journey in the fully electric £, Model X Pd, cruising across the capital city with a police escort to visit a children’s centre set up in her name.The Queen Rania Family and Children Centre has helped hundreds of youngsters from Jordanian, Palestinian and Syrian backgrounds, and hundreds of refugees, with holistic therapies to combat the stress of gender based violence.Get our daily newsletter for the latest news on the Queen, Charles, Kate, Wills, Meghan, Harry and the rest of The Firm. Click here to sign up Set up in  by the Jordan River Foundation , one of the royal family’s central charitable foundations, the centre has devised a programme to educate young girls on topics which have often been taboo in the region such as personal hygiene, personal space and emotional intelligence.Camilla was first introduced to a group of young boys and girls at ‘The Little Home’ initiative which is aimed at creating a safe space for children to share their feelings on violence or sexual abuse in the home.Camilla chatted to several children around six areas that the youngsters can rotate around as part of an exercise to enable them to open up.In these areas, the children learn to express and share emotion safe touch the circle of trust, helping to build self-esteem and self-awareness safety in the home and the danger of strangers, how to identy, run away and tell. Speaking to one young girl through an interpreter, Camilla asked: “Do you like coming here  “It must be helpful to have your friends here with you and I can see you are all helping each other.” At one of the stations in the room the Duchess and Queen Rania were shown a game where children who are between seven and  years old can use a whiteboard to take part in another exercise.By drawing several circles, one inside the other, the children can place small figurines inside each one in order to say who they most trust in their familyever they were suffering from distress. Bending down gently next to one young lass, with her hands on her knees, once again speaking through an interpreter Camilla said: “It’s wonderful you can do this. You must be very clever. After speaking to the child in Arabic, Queen Rania turned to Camilla and said: “We are all about providing an opportunity for expression for the children here.“It is their space for them to learn and be themselves.” Camilla replied: “It’s a wonderful place and so important.” In a side room Camilla was taken to meet a group of girls aged between  and  who were receiving a le skills lessons on early child marriage.  Outside the playroom, Queen Rania took Camilla to meet several women connected to the Jordan River Foundation who have been helped to set up their own businesses in traditional Jordanian crafts.At the first stall the royal pair sat on a bench while two women showed them their traditional methods for making rugs.Queen Rania said: “This is one of the traditions that has existed for such a long time in our country andsuch is in danger of being lost which is why we have to preserve it.” Camilla called the women’s products “stunning”.At one of the stalls Camilla was told about a partnership between JRF and the global furniture company IKEA which has provided jobs to both Jordanian and Syrian refugee women.Since the refugee crisis began in , nearly , Syrians have officially registered as refugees in Jordan, a country of only . million people.The project aims to engage  artisans by the end of . Camilla was shown a range of hand made pillows which are being made for Jordanians to buy and help the women employed by the scheme.Finally Camilla was given a tea set as a gt by one of the crafts people who told her: “We want you to have this to remember.” The Duchess said: “That is marvelous, I will definitely use it, thank you.” Before leaving Camilla was asked to sign her name in a plaster cast of a small hand which one of the children had made in a class called ‘The Power of Art’Organisers said the concept is to show “a helping hand is always there to guide you through your troubles”.Comment MORE ON The QueenPrince WilliamRoyal FamilyPrince Charles, Prince of Wales" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get our daily royal round-up direct to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. story: Queen says none of us can slow passage of time after being forced to cancel key eventHer Majesty shared a poignant message about bereavement with the Church of Englands national assembly - the General Synod - through her youngest son, Prince Edward the Earl of WessexThe Queens poignant message was shared with the Church of England General Synod through her youngest son, Prince Edward the Earl of Wessex Image: Tim Graham Photo Library via Getty ImagesByRussell MyersRoyal editor:,  Nov Updated:,  Nov | commentsThe Queen has said None of us can slow the passage of time in a poignant message to the General Synod given by Prince Edward in her absence due to illness. The -year-old monarch reminisced about her late husband Prince Philip, remarking how it has been half a century since they together attended the very first meeting of the General Synod.In the speech to the Church of Englandaposs national assembly, the Queen praised our richly erse modern society which the well-being of the nation depends on the contribution of people of all faiths, and of none.The monarch also used the address to describe the coronavirus pandemic as a period of anxiety, of grief, and of weariness. After missing the Remembrance Sunday service at the weekend, the Queen was due to appear in person at the Synod, but her appearance was cancelled last week.Get our daily newsletter for the latest news on the Queen, Charles, Kate, Wills, Meghan, Harry and the rest of The Firm. Click here to sign up Edward, who read the -year-old head of stateaposs speech to bishops and clergy at Church House, the Westminster headquarters of the Church of England, praised the institution for offering hope during the pandemic. Before the speech, he said the Queen sends her sincere and deep apologies that she cannot be here today. Edward added: I think you probably understand why, and she regrets that deeply. It comes after it was shared that the seven top ranking royals, affectionately dubbed the Magnicent Seven, will be stepping in to help with the Queenaposs diary for as long as is needed. Courtiers are also set to scaled down Her Majestyaposs engagements until spring, sources revealed. The monarch continues her doctor-ordered rest at Windsor Castle after being forced to pull out of attending the Remembrance Sunday service at the Cenotaph. On Sunday, the Duchess of Cambridge Kate Middleton took centre stage at the service to commemorate Britainaposs war dead. Kate looked solemn as she stood in the middle with the Duchess of Cornwall and Sophie Wessex at her sides on a balcony of the Foreign Office while Prince Charles, Prince William, Princess Anne and Prince Edward were below as they laid wreaths at the Cenotaph.Buckingham Palace has moved to dampen fears over Her Majestyaposs condition after announcing the -year-old had suffered an “unfortunate” back strain, which left her “deeply disappointed” to miss the event. Courtiers are no understood to be taking a “cautious approach” with the sovereign’s diary moving forward, with no public engagements expected for the rest of the year. story: Size  fitness coach in tears after customer calls her too fat to be goodZara Groves, , had a little cry when a friend told her a woman, who was a potential customer, saw a photo of her and decided not to sign up with herZara Groves, , was told that a customer chose not to train with her after seeing what she looked like Image: Zara GrovesByShiler MahmoudiMari Jones:,  Nov Updated:,  Nov | commentsA fitness instructor said she was left speechless after being told by a woman that she was too fat to be a good coach. Zara Groves, , was shocked when a friend told her a woman, who was a potential customer, saw a photo of her and decided not to sign up with her. She said that the comment caused her to have a aposlittle cryapos. The fitness instructor, from Llandudno, Wales, was surprised that her skill and expertise was dismissed so easily and that her experience of working in the industry for over  years was overlooked, reports the Daily Post. She has worked all over the world including Asia, Europe and Australia and runs her own fitness company, Zara Groves Fitness.  Zara said: My friend who told me about what the woman said was mortied when she realised how upset I was. Apparently the woman knew all about me and was going to sign up to one of my online courses, but then saw a photo of me on social media and instantly dismissed me as she thought me too fat, and so as a result I couldnapost possibly be a good trainer.The next day Zara dusted herself down and decided to post about what happened to her on Facebook.In my Facebook post I say clearly I know Iaposm not fat, Iaposm a size  which isnapost fat at all, said Zara. I may have put weight on since my s but the thing is Iaposm  now and Iaposm also peri-menopausal.  She continued: Iaposm just really shocked about how judgemental people can be and also how harsh. Iaposm very body confident, I really am but I know some younger fitness trainers who would have felt crucied by someone not going to them because they were deemed fat. Iaposve had some of them contact me saying similar things have happened to them and how horribly upsetting it has made them feel. I think people have a very unrealistic vision of how women and fitness trainers should look, some seem to think we should all be like was. Zara added: Just because Iaposm not a stick doesnapost mean Iaposm not a good trainer, I know I am as Iaposm still in the business  years on. And the thing is with me I keep it very real and natural. title: van driver who ran over
story: Van driver who ran over and killed mum-of-four in row over sex is jailedJames Martin, , drove away with Stella Frew, , hanging on to the side of his van in Sutton, south London, before she hit a parked car and fell under the wheelsJames Martin has been jailed for four and a half years for running over and killing a woman Image: PAByEmily PenninkRyan MerrieldReporter:,  Nov | commentsA van driver was described as cheap, cynical and disdainful as he was jailed for four and a half years for running over and killing a woman. James Martin, , drove away with Stella Frew hanging on to the side of his van in Sutton, south London in July last year. As he zigzagged through parked cars, the -year-old victim hit an Audi and fell under the van wheels, the Old Bailey was told. Martin fled the scene as members of the public rushed over to help Ms Frew, who had suffered extensive injuries and died at the scene. The court had been told the incident appeared to have been sparked by the defendantaposs refusal to pay her for sex.  Martin had also driven off with the victimaposs handbag in his van, which he later threw into the road. Ms Frew, who had four children and four grandchildren, had problems with drugs and drink and was said to have been out of her head when she approached Martin. Prosecutor Jonathan Polnay said: She was obviously very desperate to obtain money and she would not have been willing to leave with out it - and still less without her handbag. Martin had initially denied wrongdoing but had pleaded guilty to causing Ms Frewaposs death by dangerous driving on what would have been the first day of his trial. Judge Richard Marks QC rejected Martinaposs case that Ms Frew was not hanging onto the van as he drove off. The judge also noted that Martinaposs expressions of remorse were largely centred on the effect on himself and his family and he had shown little empathy for his victim.  Judge Marks told Martin: She did not deserve to die in the circumstances that she did. It is clear from the evidence that she got dragged along the road, coming into contact with a parked vehicle. Your van drove over her body causing her fatal injuries. She had a tyre mark vertically up her back from her pelvis to her neck. Your behaviour in the course of this incident and in particular at and towards the end of the incident was cheap, cynical and disdainful. He said Martin was only thinking of himself when he drove off, despite the risk to Ms Frew. The judge went on: Having driven away not having paid her a penny piece... you demonstrated the contempt for which you held her by throwing her handbag from the window. Given the lateness of Martinaposs guilty plea, Judge Marks gave him only a % discount on his sentence, handing him four and a half years in prison.  Martin was disqualied from driving for four years upon his release from jail. The judge commended the dignity shown by Ms Frewaposs family who wiped away tears in court as Martin was sentenced by video link from Belmarsh prison. Earlier, Ms Frewaposs two grown-up daughters had described their motheraposs troubled le in which they said she had suffered abuse at the hands of men. Frankie Cottrell said: Stella was a vulnerable young woman exploited by many due to her kindness, especially by men. It pains us that Stellaaposs le has been ended by the actions of a male too. She went on: She was somebody, she had a family who love her dearly. Mr Martin may have thought my mum was worthless but to us she was everything. Georgie Cottrell described her mother as the kindest, most warm-hearted woman. She said: In her le she had always been abused and hurt by men and that is why this pains us all so much - that she had died due to one too.Most ReadDont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON PrisonsPrison sentenceCrimeDangerous driving" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: what its really like working
story: What its REALLY like working at McDonalds Drive-Thru - panic alarm to secret camerasIve caught staff crying in the freezer and behind the bins during the obligatory mid-sht breakdown - spare a thought for us the next time you order your p cheeseburger, writes McDonalds Drive-Thru worker Dom Lee*We can see and hear everything you do while youre waiting to give your order at the speakers Image: Getty ImagesopinionByDom Lee:,  Nov Updated:,  Nov | commentsThere’s nothing more rewarding than a towering Big Mac accompanied by salty , hotfries from a McDonald’s Drive-Thru on a Friday night. But while this treat might feel like heaven, believe me, itaposs Hell working there. Whether it’s the medley of teenage lads shouting “Here comes Fatty” to me as they scoff a p cheeseburger, or the experience of witnessing a grown man rip off a Covid- protection window due to a lack of milkshakes, my six years at McDonalds have been nothing short of a flurry. After applying fresh out of high school , McDonald’s flexible hours and healthy rate of pay was extremely attractive to a skint first-year college student. And while most worry the lack of experience would be the issue with younger staff members, it’s the drama you’ve got to watch out for.  Once you’re past the three-month probation - during which most existing staff members refuse to acknowledge your existence - every fresh cohort brings a brand-new tier to Macciesapos ever growing political chain. However, the real initiation isn’t complete without the obligatory mid-sht breakdown. I can’t tell you how many people I’ve caught crying in the freezer, the stock room, even behind the bins. It’s a rite of passage for new staff members. Keeping a brave face is at least  percent of the job. From the Friday stampede of orders , to shovelling the remnants of half-chewed chicken nuggets from abandoned trays into the bin, and even having abuse hurledfor receiving cold food “after waiting for half an hour” always half an hour.It’s all just a part of the job.  That’s not to say every customer is rude, though. But there are the ones who test patience in a busy Drive-Thru. Firstly, nothing is LESS funny than when people try and order a Wicked Zinger Box Meal. Secondly, on behalf of every McDonald’s worker, we don’t serve mayonnaise. I don’t know why we don’t serve mayonnaise I don’t know IF we will ever serve mayonnaise and “speaking to the manager” about the lack of mayonnaise certainly isn’t going to solve anything. Thirdly, we can hear and see everything you do while you’re waiting to give your order by the Drive-Thru speakers. I can’t tell you how many solo renditions of cringe ‘s pop hits I’ve heard over the years. Alas, the serenade of freshly driving teens and those who queue for half an hour for the sake of a bottle of waterblocks out the eight hours of incessant beeping machines. *The writeraposs name has been changed.
