title: woman finds long lost dad
story: Woman finds long-lost dad after  years thanks to DNA kit she took at homeKelly Pinkney, , was bullied at school for her dark complexion despite her mums family all being fair. However, she was able to finally find answers after tracking down her Iranian dad, Saeed Sotoudeh, from an ancestry DNA testKelly, , had never known who her dad was and decided to do a £ DNA test when she saw them on sale Image: Triangle NewsByEmily HallShiler Mahmoudi:,  Nov | commentsA woman who did an ancestry DNA test has found her long-lost dad after  years.Kelly Pinkney had done the test to find out about her ancestry, but was shocked find a first cousin who led her to her dad.After tracking him down, she met up with her dad, Saeed Sotoudeh, for the first time earlier this year.She had been conceived in a short fling and was taken into the care system as a young child. Kelly,  is now forging a relationship with her dad who she was never able to find as her mum did not remember his name. She said: Itaposs such an amazing feeling knowing who I am for the first time.When I look in the mirror I look at myself in a dferent way than I did before. I feel complete. I feel like I belong now.Kelly was born in September  and was conceived the Christmas before in a one night stand in a London hotel room. She was raised by her single mum but grew up moving between foster homes before settling with a family for four years.She describes herself as a sad and unhappy child who started to run away.As she was reaching her pre-teens, she began questioning her identity, as she was dark-haired and dark-skinned with brown eyes despite her mumaposs family being fair.Kelly said: I got bullied at school because further north there were no black people, no brown people.Iaposm not even that dark, but I was the darkest kid in the school, the only kid that was brown, everyone  was white.My colour became a thing for me. That was really hard as I was in a childrenaposs home so I was dferent anyway, I didnapost have a family and I was also dferent because I had colour and no-one  did.If I was white, no-one would ever have questioned me.She moved back in with her mum aged ten and began asking her about her dad, but her mum could not give her a definite answer and said she thought he as Egyptian or Arabic.Mum didnapost know she was pregnant until eight or ten weeks, Kelly added.She said people said aposAre you going to get rid of it apos as there was no father and back in those days it wasnapost the done thing to be having a baby outside marriage.She was adamant she loved me and was keeping me.Then two years ago, she looked into doing a DNA test after a friend told her she had done one with Calornia-based Me.  At the time, the test was £ and Kelly couldnapost afford it, but a few months later she bought one on sale for £. Five weeks after sending a saliva sample. she received the results that said she was % Persian from Iran and that she had a first cousin on the site. Kelly reached out to the man and explained her story, and the cousin told her that his mum had six brother, meaning that one would be her dad.Two had died, two lived in the US and others hadnapost been in London in the late s, but he agreed to speak to his mum.I didnapost want to cause any trouble but then again I was so excited about this discovery, Kelly said. But he rang me back and instantly his tone had changed.He said there was a mistake and his mother and grandmother said it wasnapost possible as the family hadnapost come to the UK until the late s. He thought the company had made a mistake.He wished me good luck and then cut me off. But I knew the DNA couldnapost be wrong so I started doing my own research - I was literally like an FBI agent.She tracked down two of the brothers on Facebook who did not speak to her, but she was able to speak to their daughters , along with a brother, agreed to a DNA test.The results determined they were uncles and cousins, but as word spread, Kelly received another message from one of the brothers Saeed who lives in London. He said he recognised Kellyaposs mum and after a test, he was revealed to be her father. After  years Kelly had finally found the father she had been missing all her le - and amazingly his one regret in le was that he had never had kids of his own. She felt relieved that she finally understood her heritage and questions around her identity were solved. Kelly said: When I found out I cried uncontrollably for an hour. I couldnapost stop. I thought of all the hurt and pain. There was massive relief - I finally knew who I was. He never met the right person, got married or had a family of his own and he said he always wanted children. And he was the only brother out of all of them who had no children. It was a massive shock for him as heaposs never known I was out there whereas I knew he was.She now plans to meet her grandmother who is also in the UK, and further cousins in the US who she has built up a close relationship with, in the coming months.She added: I donapost want my dad to feel guilty or sad about what weaposve missed because the past is done and dusted, we canapost get it back.We have to be so grateful and happy we have this becauseI hadnapost done that test he would never have known about me. He would have spent the rest of his le alone. And for that Iaposm so grateful.A spokesman for Me said: With genetic testing readily available to consumers, we are increasingly hearing stories of families discovering and reuniting with newfound relatives, and of customers finding unexpected results in their reports.Although andMe was not designed specically to help people confirm parentage or find biological parents, our DNA Relatives tool does help people find and connect with participating genetic relatives. This feature is completely optional, meaning customers must actively choose to participate and are informed up front that by using the tool, they may discover unexpected relationships. title: working mcdonalds harder oxbridge degree
story: Working at McDonalds is harder than Oxbridge degree - and my flatmates couldnt wash upEarning minimum wage just to have customers bad-mouthing me was tough... even tougher than working on my Cambridge degree, writes Elizabeth HaighI would get home and quite literally collapse to the floor. Then I would have to get up again because there was housework, A-level coursework, or revision to do Image: Getty ImagesopinionByElizabeth Haigh:,  Nov | commentsWhat would you do for £. an hour  Not a lot, I imagine. Aged  I worked nine-hour shts at McDonald’s for this measly sum, saving towards university while doing a job that is, without a doubt, harder than an Oxbridge degree. And you can trust me: I’ve done both. Shts at McDonald’s are far from a golden time. Spent running around, never sitting down, under constant pressure to deliver meals within the magic -second window, all the time fixing a smile on your face and saying hurried, robotic company mantras: “Enjoy your meal!” Sounds exhausting  It is. Not to mention the frequent abuse, bad-mouthing and often flat-out lies from customers angling for a free Big Mac .  I would get home and quite literally collapse to the floor. Then I would have to get up again because there was housework, A-level coursework, or revision to do. Flash forward a year, and Iaposd just arrived at the University of Cambridge. I come from a low-income, single-parent household from the back of beyond in Shropshire. I was excited, nervous, and finally free. But I was not prepared for the culture shock I was about to experience.  The majority of my new friends were privately educated. Some of them had never had a job at all, let alone a customer service job. As term began, I became increasingly incredulous as I had to advise some of myfriends on everything from how to use a scourer, to how to wash up and cook pasta. And break the news that no, you can’t just add tomato purée to plain pasta and expect it to turn into the delicious vegetable sauce your mother makes. I went from flipping burgers and swearing as the milkshake machine broke again , to attending fancy formals with menus where I barely understood half the words on the page.Cambridge was tough. The workload was overwhelming and, at times, it felt like I was drowning in deadlines. If you turn up to McDonald’s at nine in the morning, or more often, six, there’s no-one interrogating your most recent essay on the philosophical value of th century French literature, asking you questions until you can’t string two words together anymore. But for all its reputation, Cambridge is the very definition of work hard, play hard. I would study for eight hours every day and despair that no matter how much time I spent, it was never enough. But then there were the formals, the balls, the nights out with friends that made it all worth it. My college became my family, and its people my community. McDonald’s is tougher than an Oxbridge degree. It is bone-wearying, relentless, and without any of the fun. But it also taught me to be grateful for every penny I have, and to appreciate the degree that enables me to do what I love. And no Oxbridge degree could have taught me that. Courtney Rogers is now expecting her th child and says she doesnapost care that her family are slammed by keyboard warriors. The stay at home -year-old, from New Mexico in the US, was a virgin when she married pastor Chris, , in October . The couple have never used contraception and have welcomed a new addition annually since they tied the knot with Courtney saying she had always wanted kids. The kids of the proud parents all begin with the letter aposCapos.  They are Clint , Clay, , Cade, nine, Callie, nine, Cash, seven, Colt six, Case also six, Calena, four, Caydie, three, Coralee two, and Caris, who is almost one. story: Town mayor facing  years behind bars for sharing revenge porn of ex-partnerAndrew Bradshaw, the mayor of Cambridge, in the United States, is facing up to  years behind bars and a massive quarter of a million dollar fine for sharing revenge porn of his ex-girlfriendAndrew Bradshaw, Mayor of Cambridge, MarylandByChris Murphy Kieren Williams:,  Nov Updated:,  Nov | comments A town mayor is facing up to  years behind bars and a quarter of a million dollar fine for sharing so-called revenge porn of an ex-girlfriend.Andrew Bradshaw, mayor of Cambridge, in the United States, is facing charges that he posted explicit pictures of his ex on Reddit. If convicted, Mr Bradshaw would face a maximum of two years and a ,fine for each count. As he is facing  counts, this means he could face up to  years in prison and a fine up to a quarter of a million dollars. The pictures included naked images and often the victim’s name and other identiable information.  Get all the latest news sent to your inbox.for the free Mirror newsletter They were posted on subreddits that had names like “HumiliatingComments”, “DegradeThisPig”, “DegradedCaptions”, “Slut”, and “needysluts”. According to legal documents, photographs of VICTIM-, as she was named, were posted in the subreddit “raceplay”. The case is being brought by the Office of the State Prosecutor which claims that Bradshaw created “multiple accounts”. The documents claimed that Bradshaw distributed the photos in dozens of posts between April and May this year. The alarm was only raised when the woman herself spotted the images online. She told police Bradshaw was the only person who she had ever shared the photos with and that she hadn’t given him permission to distribute. The document alleges that most of the images were captioned with sexually degrading and humiliating comments that included worrying personal details. It alleges some of those captions included things like “The kind of white girl [redacted] love to nut on”, and “The kind of body black men love”. Others were more explicit.  An investigation was launched and the alleged IP address where the photos were uploaded from a property owned by Bradshaw in the area. State Prosecutor Charlton T. Howard said: “Using someone’s private images without their consent is a serious breach of trust and invasion of privacy, and the power and breadth of the internet makes such a violation even more egregious. “Our office is committed to protecting victims from those who abuse their positions of power and trust.” That means Bradshaw could face up to  years behind barshe is convicted at a later date and fined up to a quarter of a million dollars. Bradshaw took office in January of this year and according to his online bio, he is the youngest mayor ever elected in the history of Cambridge. story: Egyptian ‘Sun Temple’ built for pharaohs and buried in desert for , years unearthedThe ancient remains were discovered in Abu Gorab, south of Cairo, and is believed to be one of six sun temples built some , years agoExperts found the signs of the temple whilst digging north of Egyptian archaeology locality Abusir Image: De Agostini via Getty ImagesByAlice Peacock:,  Nov Updated:,  Nov | comments Archaeologists digging in the Egyptian desert have unearthed what is touted as their biggest discovery in decades a sun temple thought to have been constructed by the pharaohs.The ancient remains were discovered in Abu Gorab, south of Cairo, and is believed to be one of six sun temples built some , years ago. Only two of these temples have been found to date. But experts like Dr Massimiliano Nuzzolo, assistant professor of Egyptology at the Academy of Sciences in Warsaw, have spent their careers trying to discover the others. The temples were built while the pharaohs of the Fth Dynasty were still alive, with the purpose of granting them the status of god. On the other hand, pyramids were built as final resting places to ensure pharaohs were resurrected as gods in the afterle.  Experts digging north of Egyptian archaeology locality Abusir first uncovered hints that a sun temple had existed in the spot, with signs of a building having sat atop the ground. It was believed the latest sun temple uncovered was built by Nyuserre Ini, an Ancient Egyptian pharaoh and the sixth ruler of the Fth Dynasty during the Old Kingdom period. Ini ruled for about  years in the th century BC. Further investigations revealed an older building base made from mud bricks and the two-foot deep base of a white limestone pillar.Experts said this suggested the original structure was “quite impressive”, according to reports fromthe .It was fty years later that researchers uncovered more proof that the old site was a temple, digging up an array of beer jars filled with mud. Experts said the tokens would have been a ritual offering reserved for the most sacred places.  Dr Massimiliano Nuzzolo, assistant professor of Egyptology at the Academy of Sciences in Warsaw, Poland, said: We knew that there was something below the stone temple of Nyuserre, but we [didnapost] knowit is just another building phase of the same temple orit is a new temple. I have now many proofs that what we are excavating here is one of the lost sun temples. Despite the now-extensive evidence that a sun temple existed on the site, it remains a mystery who the sun temple was built for and when. It was thought likely to have been constructed for a ruler from the same time period. The Fth Dynasty pharaohs ruled for about  years - from the early th century BC through to the mid th century BC. However, only a small number of rulers had sun temples created in the name of the sun god Ra, which stood on the west bank of the Nile. Lindsey and Ori Zavros and their young children Zoe and Zaneaposs camper van became bogged down in mud after heavy rains. The nearest town was about kmaway. The family, from Perth, first called for help on Friday but were told they might have to wait weeks for a land rescue because of flooding. Finally, a rescue helicopter was sent today to bring the family back to safety. A statement by South Australia Police released today says: Following a coordinated effort by emergency services, a family of four who had been stranded in the Far North of the state were winched to safety by a rescue helicopter today.  At am Friday November  police were made aware that a Mitsubishi Canter WD vehicle had become bogged in the Simpson Desert near Oodnadatta.The West Australian vehicle containing two adults and two children became stranded after bad weather and flooding on the roads.A satellite phone and supplies were dropped to the family, who were safe and well and in regular contact with the police.  Just after pm today , the family was picked up by helicopter. The family are being flown to Coober Pedy to stay the night, where they will then make their own further travel arrangements.Authorities dropped them emergency supplies including water and a satellite phone from the air while they were trapped, the BBC reports. The family had been travelling around in their campervan since last November. story: Giant razor-sharp teeth of extinct mega-shark stumbled on by chance in desertThe massive haul of giant teeth from a prehistoric megalodon shark - which would have sat in its huge ft-wide mouth - have been found in the Atacama Desert, in ChileA haul of giant teeth belonging to the prehistoric megaladon shark have been discovered in a desert Image: CIAHN HANDOUT EPA-EFE REX ShutterstockByJoe GolderRyan FaheyReporter:,  Nov  A massive haul of huge razor-sharp teeth which belonged to the biggest fish that ever lived were stumbled on in a desert by chance. The bumper find of megalodon teeth in the Atacama desert in Chile is now one of the largest scientic collections of megalodon teeth in the world. The gnashers belonged to the megalodon, a huge prehistoric shark that was alive between  and two-million years ago.An archaeologist leading the dig said the scientically-important site has recently been plundered for rare fossils which are then flogged on the black market. [Itaposs] by far the largest shark of all time, a super predator whose wingspan is estimated to be between  and  metreslong, said Atacama Palaeontologyaposs Executive Director, Pablo Quilodran.Get all the latest news sent to your inbox.for the free Mirror newsletter  He said: Although in Chile, fossils are protected by law, for many years one of the most spectacular localities, the Bahia Inglesa Formation, was the victim of destruction by deregulated mining operations and from looting by illegal fossil hunters. He added, however, that some of them had been ed to Chile, allowing it to build the worldaposs most impressive collection. Hundreds of teeth were found and sold internationally, but some have now been traced and ed to museums in Caldera and Santiago.  With this, we undoubtedly have one of the largest scientic collections of megalodon teeth in the world, he said. Explaining how the teeth from a marine animal were found in the middle of the desert, the expert said that this was because the sea level has changed over millions of years . This is visible not only in the abundant marine fossils found in sediments today, but also in the geomorphology of this part of the desert, where we can see natural esplanades, which are ancient marine terraces that testy to these dferent sea levels.  In short, the sea has receded, but the ground has also risen as a result of earthquakes and subduction of plates, phenomena that we Chileans know and experience so well. Quilodran said Charles Darwin reported having found some megalodon teeth during his trip to Chile in . But he added: However, the ersity and abundance is a novelty. And Quilodran also said that recent discoveries had put the total number of dferent shark species found in the area to . He said: In the case of sharks, it is not only Megalodon, we recently found a new sawshark record for the area, this adds up to more than  dferent species of shark that have been found in the sector. Quilodran explained a lot of these discoveries were down to sheer luck. He said: The interesting thing is that much of these findings are fortuitous and did not respond to systematic scientic activity.  The expert said it is good news that Chilean scientists will be able to continue scientic research due to recently created palaentology centres. The implications of the discoveries of megalodon teeth in the Atacama desert are huge for science, with Quilodran saying: The unusual abundance of megalodon remains in this part of the desert opens up expectations for new knowledge about many aspects of ancient le regarding this remarkable species of shark. For example, what and how did it eat  New estimates of body size, growth speed, whether it was solitary or gregarious, internal temperature and palaeoenvironmental data, among many other topics.  For its part, the Bahia Inglesa site also has an abundance of remains of bony fish, marine mammals, birds and even reptiles, and all the research potential to understand the evolution of a great ersity of dferent lineages of marine vertebrates is gigantic. The teeth will eventually end up in a museum, where the public will be able to view them. Quilodran reassured anyone with concerns of a megaladon making an appearance while paddling in the waves that itaposs categorically impossible for the beast to still be alive. No, the Megalodon became extinct due to possible climatic changes around  million years ago, he said.Although he did add that it is always possible to find new species and animals that have gone unnoticed by science, but at  metres long, it would be very dficult to have not detected it.Despite megalodon being the largest shark of all time, it is also still possible that an even greater predator preyed on it. Mr Quilodran said though the megaladon was a super predator - archaeologists have found a rival with similarly massive teeth. He said: This cetacean, a relative of sperm whales, is called Leviathan and its fossils have also been found on the Atacama coast, along with those of the Megalodon. title: model rare skin condition shares
story: Model with rare skin condition shares how shes relentlessly bullied for how she looksSonya Danita from Malaysia developed vitiligo at the age of eight and faced relentless bullying and judgment from strangers - now the -year-old is a model and an activistContent creator, body positive activist and model Sonya Danita developed vitiligo when she was eight-years-old Image: mediarum@cxpturingsouByFlorence Freeman:,  Nov Updated:,  Nov A model has spoken out on the relentless bullying she faced for her rare skin condition. Sonya Danita, , is a content creator, body-positive activist, and standing at ft ins, is also a successful model. But her journey to fulfil her modelling dream has not been smooth sailing, to say the least. The model from Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, lives with vitiligo - a long-term skin condition that leaves her body covered in pale white patches caused by the lack of melanin. Sonya developed the condition when she was eight years old when she spotted a dot on her face, which gradually spread all over her face, her hands and her legs up to her knees. Due to constant remarks on her skin, Sonya grew very self-conscious of her condition, made more so as vitiligo is a rare condition in Malaysia. She faced relentless judgment by strangers in the street who marvelled at her vitiligo. She said: I was bullied a lot for my vitiligo, a lot of people had presumptions over what I had and stared at me in the streets without shame Strangers came up to me and asked meI was a burn victim or acid victim ormy parents spilled oil on me. It wasnapost discrimination that I faced by strangers but judgement, they would just stare in this particular way. Her parents tried their hardest to find a solution to her skin condition, spending over ,on failed treatments. From ayurvedic medicine to modern medicine, to even becoming a vegetarian for two years, Sonya tried it all. The model had even suffered sunburns and peeling skin from UV light therapy. It was only until Sonya began seeing a doctor - who claimed to be injected her with natural herbs - that her skin began going back to brown. But the doctor had lied and ly claimed to be using natural herbs when in fact he was injecting Sonya with harmful steroids. She said: I started falling sick a lot and we did a blood test to find out the cause only to find out that the doctor was injecting me with steroids. After I stopped taking steroids my skin went right back to normal, it was like the steroids had pressed pause on my vitiligo nothing . But despite her hard childhood, Sonya wanted to become a model, to not only learn to embrace her vitiligo but raise awareness about vitiligo is and impact the standard of beauty in Asian Culture.  She said: I feel like itaposs very important to have these conversations because we need to pave the way for future generations Especiallywe want to create an environment which is more inclusive and more accepting and this one that does not put people into a particular box and expect them to only fit according to that box. Sonya is empowering people to know the beauty within vitiligo, speaking on the uniqueness of the condition where no two spots are the same in pattern. She concluded: Thataposs beautul, so why not embrace and celebrate it  Most ReadDont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterMORE ON " data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: woman claims feels healthier ever
story: Woman claims she feels healthier than ever thanks to diet of raw meat and eggsButcher and chef Nikolett Kiss, from Hungary, made the switch to a primal diet last year and has eaten primarily raw meat ever sinceButcher and chef, Nikolett Kiss, , of Vecsés, Swabian city, Hungary, made the switch to a primal diet last year Image: @keto.insulinresistance   CATERS NEWSByJoseph Broady:,  Nov Updated:,  Nov | commentsA woman claims she feels healthier than ever thanks to diet of raw beef, lamb and eggs Butcher and chef, Nikolett Kiss, , of Vecsés, Swabian city, Hungary, made the switch to a primal diet last year, and has consisted primarily of raw meat ever since. Nikolett spends around €a week on the freshest raw meat to suit her unique tastes. She said: “The reason I choose to eat raw meat is really because I feel fantastic when I do. “After meals, I am less bloated and have since seen a huge increase in my body both mentally and physically. “It’s a lot easier to digest and I also really enjoy the taste.” Nikolett regularly eats raw beef, lamb and eggs in her daily diet. She said: “ I have quite a erse range of meats which I enjoy eating , as well as things like liver, heart, bone marrow and brain. “I like to have lots of dferent options to eat as I never want to restrict myself to just one or two options.” Her favourite raw meat to enjoy is a brisket, aged for two to four weeks. Nikolett added: “Dry, aged beef brisket is just incredible to eat, the flavours are so bold. “I enjoy fatty steak meat in general, and always make sure it is organic, grass-fed meat, as this ensures the flavours are better and the animal was living a better le. “The fat honestly melts in your mouth like butter.” Despite traditional information suggesting it could be harmful, Nikolett is not worried about the potential risk of food poisoning from ingesting uncooked meat. She explained: “It is not something that has ever worried me since starting this diet. “The stomach acid we produce as humans is incredibly strong, and rivals the acids produced by most predators in the wild. “I have never once gotten sick from eating raw meat and do not believe I will as long as I eat well sourced, fresh cuisine.” Although she is passionate about eating raw meat, she insists describing the flavour to non-meat eaters is a dficult process. She said: “I get asked it all the time and itaposs so hard to answer because even dferent cuts of the same animal have vastly dferent tastes, depending on the animal’s diet, gender, age, and how are they treated. “Raw beef has kind of a sweet or milky tastethe cow was grass fed, but cows raised on grains can turn the flavour of the meat almost metallic.“I describe the taste of my grass fed, locally sourced beef as all the flavours of the freshest forest, because you should be able to taste all of the natural herbs and the green plants in the animals diet.”“The best part is the fat, which seriously tastes like buttery cream.” Nikolett also prefers to eat her meat unseasoned, in order to retain as much of the natural flavours as possible.  She added: “In the beginning, I tried everything to make my meat taste similar to how it would taste after being cooked., with herbs and ious sauces. “Nowadays I rarely use only salt and pepper, as the meats adopt their own unique flavours based on their treatment. “There is a reason the best steaks are made from dry aged beef, and that is because the natural flavours are far bolder and make for a more enjoyable meal.” She sources all of her meat from small businesses in and around her hometown. She said: “As a butcher, I have the benefit of knowing all the best suppliers.  “We always try to get the best meat for our customers at our family shop, with all of our products coming from slaughterhouses in the countryside. “We don’t handle industrial processed meat in any fashion, and it is not something that I wish to have included in my own diet.” Nikolett researched the carnivore diet after suffering with PCOS syndrome, with affects the oies and causes irregular periods and hormone issues. She said: “I have insulin resistance and digestion issues as well as my PCOS, so I went to the doctor in order to find a diet which better suited my conditions. “The diet which was recommended by my doctor consisted of g of carbohydrates a day and had little to no effect on symptoms.  “Before long I was feeling even worse, but since I made the switch to raw meat I have never felt better.” Her daily routine usually consists of just two meals a day, with breakfast normally skipped. Nikolett explained: “On most days I will rarely be hungry at breakfast but try to drink water and a hot beverage without sweetener or sugar. “My main meal is lunch, where I usually eat fatty beef with eggs, with something similar for dinner in the evening, often substituting the beef for raw bacon, pork, ham, or liver. “However no two days are the same and I always just try to listen to my body, occasionally skipping dinner which often means  hours without eating.”  Nikolett occasionally eats some small fruits and vegetablesshe is craving something sweeter or flavourful. She said: “I eat things like raw garlic and onionI want a bold flavour, and blueberries, raspberries and strawberries for sweet. “I normally only resort to this when I am on my period as my body craves it, but all other times I am back to primal eating. Despite the diet only beginning last year, Nikolett has been prone to the taste of raw meat in the past. She explained, “ My family are also butchers, so throughout my childhood I was always surrounded by raw meat. “I used to eat a lot of raw sausage meat growing up, which is still something I really enjoy today. “I have also eaten a lot of carpaccio and steak tartare throughout my le, so there has always been this side of me even before I made the switch full time.” Nikolett’s International truck driver husband, Roland Kiss, , is really supportive of her unique diet. She said, “My husband supports everything I do, and he is totally fine with my diet despite him not eating raw himself. “It does however mean he gets lot of steak which I cook rare for him, and what man wouldn’t love steak every day  “I have some friends which are horried, and I have had a lot of negative feedback online, but my close friends and my family are always on my side and have come to accept I am a bit of a weirdo.”You can follow Nikolett on Instagram @keto.insulinresistance.Comment MORE ON FoodDiet" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. title: red star stung late in exciting league match
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwards.RJD-sponsored Red Star welcomed Baljaffray to the Joint Campus G pitch last Saturday where the sides played out a thrilling three-all draw in a match which swung in either direction in horrendous conditions.The sides exchanged goals in the first half, with Stuart MacLean reacting quickest in the box after the Baljaffray keeper couldn’t hold a Fraser Talbot shot and the striker scored to net his eleventh goal in eight games.Baljaffray forced a succession of corners near the end of the half and were on level terms when Red Star were only able to partially clear a corner which fell to the away side’s full back and his shot via the aid of a deflection went past young Leon Murphy in the Star goal. -Into the second half and Star could have retaken the lead when Aaron Moore latched onto a drilled cross from strike partner Stuart MacLean, however, his effort was blocked by an excellent save from the Baljaffray number one.The visitors took the lead after  minutes when a cross caused confusion in the Star defence and the Baljaffray forward had the simple task of finishing into an empty net from close range.Star huffed and puffed for an equaliser, however, they were frustrated by excellent goalkeeping until the goal came in fortuitous circumstances after a long ball was nodded past his own keeper by the Baljaffray centre back meaning the sides were level with  minutes to go.Star took the lead with five minutes remaining when Aaron Moore was able to burst clear of the Baljaffray backline and finish well into the far corner to make it -.This should have been enough to see Star over the line but Baljaffray scrambled a late equaliser when Star again failed to clear a free kick and the ball was bundled over the line to see the match end -.Lochgilphead Red Star are on their travels on Saturday November  when they face their toughest test of the season so far as they take on league leaders and title favourites Arthurlie.

title: local-primary-school-children-raise-funds-poppy-scotland
story: PUPILS at St. Maryrsquos Primary School in Melrose have paid their own special tribute to former pupils who lost their lives during WW in addition to raising money for the charity Poppy Scotland in its centenary year.All of the children have been busy working in their own little poppy factory from painting sheets and sheets of crimson paper to assembling our poppies.They also researched the  young men who spent their schooldays at St. Maryrsquos and ultimately died in that war and were able to find images of  of them.These images were then inserted into large painted poppies.Head of Art at the school Debbie Wood told us: ldquoIt felt appropriate to send these precious photographs back out into the world for people to see over  years later.ldquoWe do so hope that this sparks further conversation and who knows we might find a little more information regarding these young men. The school can be contacted directlyanyone believes that they might be able to add to our memories.ldquoThe support from local business has been wonderful and we look forward to seeing our poppies hung in windows in time for Remembrance.

title: jim-telfers-contribution-world-rugby-recognised
story: BORDERS rugby legend Jim Telfer is to be inducted into World Rugbyrsquos Hall of Fame .The former Hawick High School and Gala Academy headmaster won  caps for Scotland,  as captain.And he made eight test appearances for the British and Irish Lions, on two tours, in  and .A tenacious back-row forward for Melrose, Telfer has the distinction of being the only Scotland international to have played New Zealand, South Africa and Australia without losing.Following his playing career, he became one of the most revered coaches in the game.He coached the Lions on their  tour to New Zealand, Scotland to the Five Nations Grand Slam in  and, as assistant to Sir Ian McGeechan, to a second Grand Slam in .After a break from coaching, Telfer was invited by McGeechan to become forwards coach on the triumphant Lions tour of South Africa in .Through his technical know-how and stirring motivational speeches, Telfer galvanised a Lions pack written off by the press and they laid the  for a - series victory.Telfer, with the assistance of John Rutherford and Hugh Campbell, was successful again in  as Scotland claimed the last-ever Five Nations title under their management.The six stars were selected by the Hall of Fame committee. This comprises of John Eales, David Hands, Henri Garcia, Pablo Mamone, Rob Cole, Anna Richards and Wayne Smith.Eales, the chair of the committee, said: ldquoThe  inductees for the World Rugby Hall of Fame are representative of all that is good in our game. Each of them have been outstanding players in either sevens or s and they have also been important contributors to rugby, in their own countries and globally, off the field.

title: gala-fairydean-rovers-announce-new-initiative-youngsters
story: Gala Fairydean Rovers Academy players will now be invited to all home first team matches with free entry.The Lowland League Club feel that it is important for the youngsters to see where the GFR pathway leads to.Neil Hastings has also voiced his support and looks forward to seeing all players and coaches down at Netherdale soon.He said: ldquoWhen I first arrived at the club it was clear to see there was  still is a lot of excellent work going on with the youth academy. As someone who has always had an interest in youth development and also someone who has worked at ious clubs with youth players, I understand all the dficulties and challenges along the way.ldquoFirst and foremost, when I arrived at the club I had to concentrate on the st team and this will obviously always be my number one focus. However, I now believe we are moving in the right direction, and I really want to try and create a real family environment at the club.ldquoNothing would make me happier on a Saturday to walk out at pm and see as many of the young GFR family shouting, cheering, and supporting the st team. We have the full pathway now for young players at the club from starting their football journey Up to under s football and then the lowland league side.ldquoI think its important for a young players development that they see where they are aiming to try and play. I have spoken with Davie about a few ideas to try and build a relationship between the First team and the young players as I understand its a two-way street and we cant just ask for them to come along a create an atmosphere. I would love for us to get to a point in a few yearrsquos time where we dont need to ask for ball boys, mascots or for them to attend but to hear that theyre heading to Netherdale for the game with their friends anyway.

title: a7-closure-borders-buses-suspends-x95-services-rest-day
story: BORDERS Buses has suspended X services between Hawick and Carlisle due to a closure on the A.Police were called to reports of an overturned lorryat around .am today , with officers closing the road to recover the vehicle.And Borders Buses says it has taken the ldquohard decision to stop all remaining X services for the remainder of the day due to the closure.A spokesperson for the travel company said: ldquoWe have been informed that the A closure is expected to remain in place for most of the day.ldquoAs this closure is out with our control, we have taken the hard decision to suspend all remaining X services between Hawick and Carlisle for the remainder of today.:Shona Haslam to step down as leader of Scottish Borders CouncilIt is the companyrsquos intention toto normal tomorrow, but this is ldquoonly an optionthe road reopens.According to Traffic Scotland, the A is now running under temporary traffic lights at Canonbie following the overnight incident.Meanwhile, police have confirmed that a crash took place in Stow last night.There were no injuries, according to officers.A Police Scotland spokesperson said: ldquoWe received a report of a road traffic crash involving a car and a lorry on the A Galashiels Road in Stow around .pm on Thursday, November , .ldquoThere were no injuries reported and vehicle recovery was arranged.

title: edinburgh-christmas-market-2021-opening-dates-times
story: Christmas is already on the horizon, bringing with it Edinburghs famous markets after a two-year hiatus.The pandemic may have put a halt to the annual markets last year, but this year they are due back in all their festive glory.Edinburghs markets are famous and see thousands of people flock to Princes Street Gardens to get in on the action.This year will be no dferent, so heres everything you need to know about the Edinburgh Christmas markets ...Edinburgh Christmas market dates and opening timesThere are ious markets across the city, which have slightly dferent dates and opening times.The West Princes Street Gardensmarketwill open on Friday November  and run until Saturday January , operating between the hours of am to pm.The George Street eventwill also open on Friday November  until Saturday January from the hours of am to pm.Meanwhile the East Princes Street Gardensmarketwill open at lunchtime on Saturday November .Where are the dferent Edinburgh Christmasmarkets There are markets in three locations in Edinburgh.The West Princes Street Gardens market is accessible from The Mound, Princes Street and Kings Stables Road.The George Street market will take place just up the road on George Street, while the East Princes Street Gardens market can be accessed from Princes Street and Market Street.Where can I park for the Edinburgh Christmas markets If you are attending the West Princes Street Gardens or East Princes Street Gardens markets, there is pay and display available onFrederick Street, George Street, Hanover Street and Waterloo Place.For the George Street market, pay and display parking is available onCharlotte Square, Frederick Street, George Street and Hanover Street.How  can I travel to the Edinburgh Christmas markets There are plenty of transport options to Edinburgh Christmas markets that dont require a car..removeWaverley train station is located within a -minute walk of all three markets, as is the Edinburgh bus station.What will feature at the Edinburgh Christmas markets AtWest Princes Street Gardens there will be  market stalls,  fairground rides, a bar and the information point and box office.The East Princes Street Gardens will feature  market stalls, the Big Wheel, the Double Carousel, a bar, a box office and information point and toilets.George Street will host an ice rink, three market stalls and a bar.

title: selkirk-invited-take-part-canadian-christmas-festival
story: SOUTERS are once again invited to take part in an international Christmas event with other towns and cities named Selkirk.Last year the town was invited to join the Holiday Alley festival held in the city of Selkirk in Manitoba, Canada, which was forced online due to the coronavirus pandemic.As part of the festival in , Selkirk communities around the world were invited to film themselves singing and dancing to a version of the  Days of Christmas. However, this year those wanting to get involved will be singing and dancing along to Dance in the Street, Again ndash written by Selkirk, Manitoba, artist Brenton Thorvaldson and based on the original song Dancing In The Street by Martha and the Vandellas.Organisers of Holiday Alley have also prepared choreography for Souters to follow or you can create your own moves.All the submitted videos will then be edited together in the lsquoWorldwide Dancing in the Street Videorsquo that will air on Holiday Alley web-TV on Tuesday, November . Anyone wishing to take part in this yearrsquos video, should submit their contributions to the Holiday Alley team by November . Visit: forms.gle NDfzbEshVpsEMJ

title: coldstream-man-given-unpaid-work-admitting-offences
story: A -YEAR-OLD man has been ordered to carry out a total of  hours unpaid work after being involved in two incidents in his home town in the Borders.William Sinclair, of Coldstream, pleaded guilty to obstructing police officers and running away from them on September  last year as well as behaving in a threatening or abusive manner, shouting and swearing and threatening police officers.Then in the Clock Tower Sports Bar in Coldstream he assaulted his partner by pushing her against a wall, striking her in the face and pushing her to the ground to her injury.Defence lawyer Mat Patrick said alcohol was a factor in both incidents.But he claimed the partner had got caught in the middle when Sinclair was lashing out at his brother during the disturbance in the bar.

title: borders-volunteers-join-great-borders-river-clean
story: VOLUNTEERS across the Borders grabbed their bin bags last weekend to help support the Great Borders River Clean.Almost  communities in the region took part in the clean-up which aims to remove waste a debris from local rivers between Friday and Sunday. Over the weekend more than  volunteers gathered, collecting around ,kg of rubbish.Tom Rawson, founder of Green Tweed Eco and the Great Borders River Clean, said: ldquoThis was the fourth edition of a series of region-wide events that have seen over ,kg of rubbish removed from the Tweed, Teviot and major tributaries.ldquoWith the support of Tweed Forum and the Fallago Environment Foundation, the Great Borders River Clean has grown into one of the UKrsquos largest river clean events.Volunteers joined river clean groups in Ancrum, Peebles, Melrose, Darnick, Chirnside, Tweedbank, Galashiels, Coldstream, Innerleithen, Traquair, Hawick, Selkirk, Walkerburn, Earlston, and Kelso.Mr Rawson, who is a teacher at St Maryrsquos Primary School in Melrose, added: ldquoPerhaps most exciting, this edition saw the involvement of school groups with pupils from Earlston High, Ancrum and Newtown St. Boswells primary schools working really hard to rid their local streams of rubbish.ldquoNewtown St. Boswells Primary School even made a superb film of their efforts.ldquoThis is something that I would like to encourage in future and I am currently seeking to raise funds for the introduction of a Borders-wide prize to encourage participation and the engagement of young people in the fight against rubbish and littering.ldquoAt a time when the world was focused on events at COP in Glasgow, it was lovely to see the towns and villages of the Borders working together to improve the natural environment at a local level.

title: officers-recommend-wearing-reflective-clothing-dark-nights
story: POLICE in the Scottish Borders have issued road safety advice now that the darker evenings are here about what everyone can do to keep safe when out and about this winter.Officers recommend wearing reflective or bright-coloured clothing so other road users can see you clearly.If walking home, particularly late at night, make sure someone knows where you are and when you are expected to arrive at your destination.Vehicles can take up to  x longer to stop on wet surfaces so take extra care crossing the road.Dont cross the road between or behind vehicles.If there is no pavement, keep to the right hand side of the road so you can see traffic coming towards you.Do not cross the road while distracted, for example, whilst using your phone.Follow all traffic signs and signals and before you go to cross the road, as you may not be aware of dangers such as ice, pot holes or deep puddles that can cause injury.Find more safety advice for darker winter evenings visit http:ow.ly HwgpGzr

title: christmas-lights-switch-on-returns-peebles
story: LAST Christmas, Peebles High Street was aglow with lights, but the festive spirit at the most wonderful time of year was missing.It was, as many called it, a COVID Christmas.Light switch-on events were cancelled and the streets, usually filled with people enjoying mulled wine while listening to the children singing carols, were empty.However, lsquotis the season to be jolly this year, and Christmas in Peebles will begin early ndash with the grand switch-on happening at the end of November.Spirited volunteers got together on Sunday, November  and are busy working to create a dazzling event for the community.:Borders GP takes part in climate protest die inCommittee member Malcolm Bruce said: ldquoThe installation work is going well this year despite an early delay due to inclement weather. The next stage will see us working with a high reach machine installing the big wall decorations and the lsquoWelcome to Peeblesrsquo sign at the Leckie Church.ldquoThese didnrsquot all make an appearance last year due to COVID working restrictions, so it will be nice to see the streets back to being fully illuminated.The organisation has also invested a considerable sum of money this year in moving entirely to LED bulbs.ldquoThese save on power and are much safer to handle when up a ladder, said Malcolm. The committee is also calling for some younger elves to join the merry team.Malcolm added: ldquoWe are a happy bunch of volunteers who spend a lot of time in the run-up to December installing the lights for the pleasure of the people of Peebles.ldquoWe are an ageing group, and it would be greatsome younger members of the community could join us in future to learn the ropes and maybe take over when they are ready to. title: newtown-st-boswells-play-park-officially-opens
story: A NEW play park has officially opened in Newtown St Boswells.The pound, site is part of Scottish Borders Councils pound.million investment in play parks and outdoor community spaces programme.The accessible for all park is suitable for children aged from three-years-old to  and is the second destination play park to be opened this year ndash a play park at Peebles Victoria Park opened in May.Selkirkshire councillors, Gordon Edgar, Caroline Cochrane and Elaine Thornton-Nicol, said: ldquoThis new, custom-built play park in Newtown St.Boswells is an extremely exciting development for the local area.ldquoItrsquos absolutely crucial when creating a facility like this that it is designed to meet the needs of the people who will use it most and it was extremely pleasing to be able to include local primary school children throughout the design process and get their input and feedback throughout.The park includes a specially design safety surfacing mural which depicts the Newtown St Boswells area and has a central multi-play unit.Eildon Housing Association gave more than pound, and Buccleuch Estates gave more than pound, to the development of the park.As part of the councils ongoing play parks programme, facilities in Duns and Jedburgh are set to open in  in addition to ongoing plans for a skate pump track in Jedburgh and skate park in Peebles.SBC convener councillor David Parker said: ldquoThe Council has made major strides in the last few years in bringing our play park and outdoor community spaces up to date with outstanding modern facilities.ldquoThis new play facility will rank as one of the best in the Borders and will signicantly enhance the community facilities on offer for our young people.ldquoI have no doubt this will make a positive contribution to the local area and will offer countless hours of fun and enjoyment to young people in the Borders.

title: learn-becoming-teacher-scottish-borders
story: THE SCOTTISH Borders Council are looking to hear from graduates currently living in the Borders who would be interested in obtaining a qualication that would allow them to gain GTCS registration as a primary or secondary teacher.The opportunity is being provided through a partnership agreement with the University of Highlands and Islandswho offer a Professional Graduate Diploma in Educationprimary or secondary programme for graduates with a degree.Alongside opportunities to train to teach in the primary sector, the secondary courses offered are:biology with science, business education, chemistry with science, computing science, English, home economics, mathematics, physics with science and technological educationAn Honours degree at : or above is preferred as the programme sits at Honours and Masters levels. Applicants must also hold National  Mathematics and Higher English . At secondary level there are specic entry guidelines for inidual subjects.The programme is full time for one year with students required to carry out online, collaborative and inidual study, interspersed with school placements. Please note that all arrangements will be subject to relevant COVID- restrictions.Upon completion of the programme, students will apply for the GTCS Teacher Induction Scheme to be offered a yearrsquos probationary teacher position in a Scottish Borders school. They will then be entitled to apply for posts within the local authority.The closing date for applications for the August  academic year is  January .Anyone who is interested in finding out more is invited to take part in one of the following virtual drop-in sessions:Wednesday  November, -pm or Tuesday  November, -pmTo find out more and to get details on how to access the sessions, email: CPD@scotborders.gov.uk or phone  ..removeCouncillor Shona Haslam said: ldquoThis really is an exciting and innovative way for anyone with a relevant degree to join us. title: nicola-sturgeon-covid-update-say-today-new-rules-considered
story: Nicola Sturgeon was back giving a Covid update today in Parliamentafter a two-week hiatus due to COP hosting duties.In her absence over the past two Tuesdays, health secretary Humza Yousaf and deputy first minister John Swinney stepped in, with the latter warning last week that changes to the current rules could be on their way.Indeed, today not only marked the First Ministersto the Covid briefings, but also the three-weekly review of the restrictions currently in place, when the government decides whether to adapt current measures.The past two days have seen a flurry of Covid related announcements Boris Johnson gave a press briefing yesterday in which he refused to rule out the reintroduction of restrictions in England, and the vaccine booster scheme was extended to include --year-olds.Nowin the aftermath of COP, which experts warned could lead to a spike in cases, the Scottish government is consideringimplementing some changes to the current Covid measures in Scotland.Heres everything you need to know.... Current regulations remain in place with no changesToday marked the three-week review of Covid rules, with the Scottish government deciding not to implement any changes at the moment.However, the First Minister did confirm they were considering making changes to the current rules on vaccine passports, with a decision due to come in the coming days.. Vaccine passports in hospitality settings being consideredLast week deputy first minister John Swinney said the government was considering extending the use of vaccine passports to wider hospitality settings.Today, the First Minister confirmed that these changes were still under consideration.If such measures are introduced, it would meanpeople wouldrequire vaccine passports to visit venues such as indoor theatres,cinemas and some licensed hospitality venues, as well as nightclubs and large scale events.Any changes would be introduced from December , according to the First Minister..remove. COP did not lead to a signicant rise in casesDespite experts warning before the climate conference that we could see Covid figures surge, this does not currently appear to be the case, according to the First Minister.She said that although we couldnt draw "finalconclsuions" as of yet, "there is no sign so far of any signicant spike in cases associated with COP".The First Minister also used the example of COP as a reason to use lateral flow tests, which she advised people took twice a week as well asremindingthe public that these tests can be ordered online for free.. --year-olds will be invited to book their booster jabs soonYesterday it was confirmed that people aged - in Scotland would be offered a Covid booster jab, after results found that a third dose signicantly improved protection.On Monday, the online portal opened for over-s in Scotland to book their booster jabs, with the First Minister confirming over-s would be invited for their boosters once the top priority groups were vaccinated.Booster jabs can only be given -weeks or  months after receiving the second dose of the Covid jab.. Covid cases are rising slightly in ScotlandDespite COP not yet seeming to have a huge impact on figures in Scotland, the First Minister did confirm that Covid cases were rising slightly, with the daily average up to around ,.In the last  hours, , new cases of Covid were reported, while  people were in hospital and in intensive care.A further  deaths were recorded.Speaking on these figures, the First Minister said: "The numbers reported in recent days here in Scotland - which Irsquoll come on to talk about - illustrate the need for continued precautions. So too does the challenging situation being experienced again across Europe."Drawing on infection rates in Germany and Austria among other European nations experiencing surging Covid numbers, Ms Sturgeon added: "All of this is a reminder that governments everywhere are grappling with the same issues and dilemmas we are.". Covid rates in older population decliningCovid case rates may be rising slightly, but they are decreasing amongst the older population.Infection rates in the + age group are declining, which the first minister suggested was likely linked to the Covid booster jab, with  million third doses administered.. Scotland most vaccinated area of UKThe First Minister added that Scotland was the most vaccinated nation in the UK, saying: "It is worth pointing out that on first, second, booster and third doses, Scotland is currently the most vaccinated part of the UK."That is down to the incredible hard work of everyone involved in organising and delivering the programme and I want to record my thanks to each and every one of them."

title: second-jobs-mps-borders-representatives-share-thoughts
story: THE Bordersrsquo Westminster representatives have had their say as the row over whether MPs should be allowed second jobs continues.Labour will vote tomorrowon banning MPs from taking paid directorships or consultancies in a bid Sir Keir Starmer says would help to end ldquododgy lobbying.It comes after then-North Shropshire MP Owen Paterson, of the Conservatives, was found by the Commons Standards Committee to have used his position to benefit two companies who paid him as a consultant.Mr Paterson said his integrity had been ldquorepeatedly and publicly questioned, and claimed he was ldquototally innocent of breaking lobbying rules.:Second destination play park of the year opens in Newtown St BoswellsOn the issue of second jobs, Berwickshire, Roxburgh and Selkirk MP John Lamont said: ldquoHaving been a Borders MSP and then MP for almost  years now, I know that my job takes up almost the entirety of my time.ldquoMy priority is helping constituents and representing them in Parliament.The Conservative representative added: ldquoSplitting my week between my home in Coldstream and Westminster leaves little time for anything .Earlier this month, Mr Lamont and fellow Borders representative David Mundell, also of the Conservatives, voted in favour of changing the way MPs are policed ndash pausing Mr Patersonrsquos suspension for breaking lobbying rules.:Coronavirus: Borders records more than  cases in -hour periodThis was met with outrage from opposition parties, forcing a government U-turn.When asked about MPs having second jobs, Mr Mundell ndash representative of Dumfriesshire, Clydesdale and Tweeddale ndash said: ldquoOver my  years as a Member of Parliament, I have always taken the view that this is a full-time job, and that is why I have never had a second job or had any other paid outside interest.MPs are currently allowed second jobs as long as they are not a minister.

title: first-atlas-printed-islamic-world-sold-four-times-estimate-auction
story: The first atlas printed in the Islamic world has sold for more than four times its estimate at auction, after it was discovered in an attic.The ldquoexceptionally rare Ottoman folio atlas by Mahmoud Ra Efendi was sold for pound, on Tuesday by Dreweatts, of Newbury, Berkshire.It was one of only  produced and was among several discoveries made at Weston Hall in Northamptonshire, home of the Sitwell family for more than  years.Dreweatts auction house said the Ottoman atlas was the first printed in the Islamic World.It was found in ldquoextraordinary condition in one of the nine attics at Weston Hall, stamped and dated , and featured a hand-coloured pictorial title with the monogram of Sultan Selim III, the auction house said.Written in Ottoman Turkish with  hand-coloured terrestrial maps, the atlas included two twin-hemispheres and one world, with a plain celestial chart.Denise Kelly, book specialist at Dreweatts, said: ldquoThis is a wonderful atlas. The condition of the binding, terrestrial maps and celestial chart are extraordinary. A fascinating object to come to the market.It it was thought the atlas was brought to Britain by Sitwell family member General Lord Hely-Hutchinson.On the first day of the Weston Hall and the Sitwells: A Family Legacy two-day auction, the atlas sold for more than four times its pre-sale estimate and was bought by a UK buyer.Joe Robinson, head of Dreweatts house sales department, said: ldquoWe are delighted with the result of this rare Ottoman atlas, which after competitive bidding on the phones and internet achieved over four times its low pre-sale estimate.ldquoSelling to a UK buyer, it is one of several wonderful discoveries made at Weston Hall..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagagaga, title: First atlas printed in Islamic world sold for four times its estimate at auction
